scenes.location: SAINT FRANCIS HOTEL, SAN FRANCISCO. NIGHT.
characters: THE BACK OF AN SLR CAMERA BEING LOADED WITH FILM
INT. HART CABIN, TROUBLESOME GULCH. MOMENTS LATER
INT. GRAND BALLROOM, WALDORF ASTORIA. 20 MINUTES LATER.
INT. DARTMOUTH INN BANQUET ROOM, HANOVER, NH, AFTERNOON
TAGS BEING RIPPED OFF NEW JOGGING CLOTHES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We open inside a NEWS VAN. Four monitors show different competing feeds. A waiting reporter. Color Bars. A politi commercial. One monitor is cueing up a debate clip. A light pops on the reporter and he springs to life.

dialogues.speaker: TV REPORTER
dialogues.text: Yes, we learned just a few minutes ago that Senator Hart will soon be leaving this hotel back to the convention hall, where he will concede -- yes, he will concede -- to former vice president Walter Mondale. Hart won every state -- We pull out to reveal a PRODUCER hovering over an ENGINEE

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCER
dialogues.text: His hair looks like shit. When’s he getting it cut?

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEER
dialogues.text: That is the new cut. (shakes his head) We can’t get a clear line.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Are we at full stick? The producer pops her head out to check the dish. We tilt to see people watching from above as the dish slowly rise We pan to find the blown-dry reporter. Beyond him is anot NEWSMAN, delegates, protestors, cops, etc...

dialogues.speaker: TV REPORTER
dialogues.text: -- West of the Mississippi River in this fight for the Democratic nomination. But in the end, it was Mondale’s taunting question, taken from a Wendy’s advertisement, that dogged his insurgent campaign.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCER HART, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Roll tape. Go! I think the dedication of our party to minority people in the South...  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 2. We push back into the van to see ACTUAL FOOTAGE - WALTER MONDALE at a debate with Hart.

dialogues.speaker: MONDALE
dialogues.text: I hear your new ideas, I’m reminded of that ad - Where's the beef? A ROAR of laughter and applause as Hart tries to be heard

dialogues.speaker: HART, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: If you’d listen just a minute --” We're pulling away from the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Ok, go Steve.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Senator Hart will take the stage tonight to --

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEER
dialogues.text: Hold it Steve, hold it! We lost the signal.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER PRODUCER
dialogues.text: (continuing unbeknownst) Share his thoughts with the many thousands of voters and activists who fought hard these last months. The fuck is going on up there? Talk to me. Are we facing south? (peering up at the roof) Steve, would you shut up? We lost the signal again.

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think we're facing South. Supposed to be south, yes?

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCER
dialogues.text: Well, maybe you should invest ina god damn compass.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: (continuing unbeknownst)

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would someone tell him to Senator Hart broke from relative obscurity when he took the New Hampshire primary... We pop back outside the news shut the fuck up. No one’s listening. Ah, what’s the point? van to find a couple guys we’l1l come to know as STRATTON and WILSON. Smoking cigarettes.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 3.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: «+. Guy just tried to pin my lapel. Didn’t even ask.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: How far are we from the O'Farrell Theater...? Just curious. They cross the street through traffic. Stratton tells a s about losing the tip of his finger while starting a golf as a young staffer. We boom up and find a THIRD FLOOR WINDOW. A guy we’1ll co know as EMERSON is sitting on the sill. He’s wearing a WH ELECTION HAT. It reads “HART”. He takes it off, examines one last time, then tosses it down to the street below. INT. VIP SUITE, ST. FRANCIS HOTEL. CONTINUOUS. Stratton and Wilson enter the room still jawing. The staf were cute on the McGovern campaign. We pan to find a guy we’ll come to know as BROADHURST. He smoking in the bathroom with a attractive female staffer.

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST
dialogues.text: You can’t even imagine... There ain’t nothing like sleeping on the open ocean, darling. We find Emerson grabbing a drink at a small wet bar. It’s mixed crowd. Staffers and donors. The mood is low key, bu people still mingle.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: What’s the plan for after?

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Can we hold off the ‘88 talks for just a moment.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: I meant drinks.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Oh, the Hawaiian place.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: It’s Polynesian. We move through bodies to find GARY HART, sitting on an a sofa, PHONE and a VODKA, finishing up the worst phone cal you can make in politics.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 4.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (cradling a corded phone) Yeah, OK. I appreciate it, Walter. His wife and college sweetheart LEE, wipes an eye and hol his arm. He makes meaningful eye contact with BILL DIXON. Nearby are his son and daughter, JOHN and ANDREA.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to his wife Lee, quietly) I‘1l1 come with you back to Denver.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You should stay. Nearby, JOHN EMERSON chats up BILLY SHORE about the Russi Olympic boycott. Stratton checks his watch and shows Shore the time. He no Wilson pulls out speech and checks it one last time. Stratton and Shore approach the sofa where Hart sits.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: It’s time, Senator.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON SHORE
dialogues.text: (to Hart) (to Wilson) Remember to hit homelessness. Doug. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (to Lee) I don’t want you to fly alone.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I’ll take the kids. You need to be in DC.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I don’t need to be anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Yeah, you do.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON SHORE
dialogues.text: We need to roll. Gary? BILLY SHORE, late 20s, helps Gary with his suit jacket. Stratton guides the Harts toward the door.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team moves through heartbroken supporters offering ad libbed, “Don't leave... stay in it...” A couple secret service agents push through as PHOTO FLASHES POP. Wilson continues to remind about policy.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: We promised homeless to Mondale.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: People are homeless. The name of the issue is “homelessness”.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: (struggling) Come on, clear a path...

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (to Hart) And Perestroika.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: It’s a marker for ‘88.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (to Wilson) Homeless and Russians, got it. Suddenly, COMMOTION. A woman screams. The secret service agents RUSH at Hart, pushing him back towards the suite.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: What the fuck is -- Other agents converge on a man. For a moment, we see an A WITH A GUN being held up in the air.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Active shooter... Active shooter...

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Oh God! What? The agents move like a scrum, pushing them back into... INT. VIP SUITE, ST. FRANCIS HOTEL. CONTINUOUS. Hart is pulled into a corner. An agent hovering over him.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Redwood is secure.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 6. We hear reports coming in over the walkie talkies as the shares looks with each other. Stunned.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Gary.... Gary?! They all look over at Hart. The secret service agent step away to reveal him doubled over, clutching his side.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Senator?!

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: We need a paramedic in the suite. Lee gets down on her knees to help, but Hart rears up LAUGHING hysterically, barely able to breathe.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Gary!! But he can’t stop laughing. After a long beat...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Who shoots the loser?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart, tie loosened, still laughing. In an image unfamilia for anyone today, Hart is drinking with his PRESS BUDDIES JACK GERMOND (The Sun) DAVID BRODER (The Post) IRA WYMAN.

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: Maybe he didn’t like your jobs plan, either.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: We've been through that. It’s a good plan... It was a good plan. Reveal we are watching from another table, over the shoul of a younger generation of reporters.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did anyone find out this guy’s reasons?

dialogues.speaker: WYMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, they found a photo of you in his wife’s purse. Off laughter, we move to the Kids Table. ALAN WEINBERG, A MCDANIEL, DAVID AXELROD drinking cheap beer.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 7.

dialogues.speaker: MCDANIEL
dialogues.text: You really want to follow Mondale around for another six months?

dialogues.speaker: WEINBERG
dialogues.text: My apartment is grim. I'll take the free meals.

dialogues.speaker: MCDANIEL
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s how I feel about my boyfriend. BOB WOODWARD stops by the big boys table.

dialogues.speaker: AXELROD
dialogues.text: Holy shit, look, it’s Woodward.

dialogues.speaker: MCDANIEL
dialogues.text: Think he still comes into the newsroom?

dialogues.speaker: WEINBERG
dialogues.text: I heard he doesn’t take a salary.

dialogues.speaker: MCDANIEL
dialogues.text: Doesn't need to. Have you seen his house?

dialogues.speaker: WEINBERG
dialogues.text: Have you? We find Hart and Woodward now at the bar sharing whiskeys

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: ... She’d have won you New Jersey if you hadn’t made that dumbass crack about the water.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: No one’s got a sense of humor anymore.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: Fuck ‘em if they can’t take a joke. (beat while he drinks) How's Lee doing?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: She needs a rest.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: Mondale did you a favor. Reagan's going to crush him.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17)

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Maybe. Probably.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: You'll have an open road in ‘88.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ‘88... right.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: Next time, they’re going to want the one thing you won't give.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: Everything else.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: OPENING TITLES
dialogues.text: And then BLACK. We hear a woman crying. TITLE SLIDE: WASHINGTON. 1987. INT. BEDROOM, GEORGETOWN. EARLY MORNING. Tammy Faye Bakker cries through runny mascara on “Charges expected in Bakker Family Scandal" The room is dark, but we find Gary’s legs on the bed. He’s pulling on his trademark COWBOY BOOTS.

dialogues.speaker: TAMMY FAYE
dialogues.text: ... And so I always say, ‘Lord, I trust you with me.' Gary stands and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A debate between GARY HART and BOB DOLE is in ful

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: President Reagan has allowed our cities to decay while he buys enough warheads to destroy the planet 30 times over. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CNN -
dialogues.text: edge of his 1 swing.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 9.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Imagine if every library could have a computer. Every school. Every home.

dialogues.speaker: DOLE
dialogues.text: Why don’t we just buy everyone a microwave? And a television set while we’re at it?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I'm interested in educating the next generation... not entertaining them.

dialogues.speaker: MODERATOR
dialogues.text: This is beginning to sound like a campaign debate... Did either of you want to announce something? Light laughter and clapping from the audience. Young peop are clearly charmed by Hart’s charisma. In the wings we find Billy Shore, four years older. He’s watching and nodding. ALAN WEINBERG approaches with a smi

dialogues.speaker: WEINBERG
dialogues.text: Mr. Billy Shore, what’s the story?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: It’s not going to happen today, Alan... But keep asking.

dialogues.speaker: WEINBERG
dialogues.text: You hear Sonny Bono announced. He’s running for mayor of Palm Springs.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Come on. I can guess his slogan. They both stumble some sort of “He’s got you babe”. INT. CONFERENCE ROOM - “HART FOR PRESIDENT” HQ, DENVER Drop-tile ceiling, 35-year old carpeting with paint to ma A college aged intern is setting up three unmatching TVs. features Hart at Georgetown. Staffers from ‘84 reuinite with hugs. Some holding suitca A PHONE TECH is trying to open the phone jack box with a screwdriver, but the screws are stripped. He grabs a smal crowbar from his bag, and pries the door off with a loud  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 10.

dialogues.speaker: PHONE TECH
dialogues.text: (coughing, sputtering) Ain’t gonna hold twenty-five lines. Mid-way through the room, 50 or so VOLUNTEERS and STAFFER are gathered in a circle, rapt, with DIXON, campaign mana

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: These other candidates, they’re all decent guys. They all want the best for this country. But they are Not Going To Win. You know it, they know it, most importantly, George Bush knows it. That’s why they’re all gunning for us. We don’t win this primary, kiss the White House good bye. And kiss your future goodbye. Because, and I don’t know how the hell this happened, but damn near all of you in here are younger than me. So it is truly your future that is at stake here. The phone tech continues to pry ceiling tiles loose, usin staple gun to drop phone cord from the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: MODERATOR, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: They call you and some of your younger colleagues the Atari Democrats.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: I've heard. I didn’t coin that.

dialogues.speaker: MODERATOR, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Have you played Atari?

dialogues.speaker: HART, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: I tried Asteroids with my son a few times. I mostly drifted around getting pelted with rocks. Felt like my first term in the senate. We find KEVIN SWEENEY (press secretary) along with Wilson IRENE KELLY (campaign scheduler) around a PHONE TREE. Wil is distracted by Hart on television.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: If line three rings, don’t pick up. That’s the fax.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: What if line one and two are busy?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 11.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY WILSON
dialogues.text: Use line four. (watching the TV) How does he look that good?

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Genetics. Swing back to Dixon building with steam withe volunteers.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: So, when you're tired and your feet hurt and your hands are freezing because you’ve been knocking on doors in Nashua for twelve straight hours. When you miss your boyfriends and girlfriends, your kids. When you’re tired of eating leftovers because we don’t pay you jack shit, you think about the opportunity we have right now, and the cost to this great country if we squander it. The future of this country is in your hands. That’s no exaggeration. It’s in your hands. Hold it carefully. INT. THE WASHINGTON POST NEWSROOM. CONTINUOUS. The newsroom’s humming as Hart’s debate continues on TV. BEN BRADLEE’s office, where the legendary editor, seated behind his desk with Watergate-era photos behind him, is meeting with about 7 editors and reporters. In the room are: ANN DEVROY (30s, the political editor), DAVID BRODER (50s, the chief political correspondent), BO WOODWARD (40s, reporter of Watergate fame), BOB KAISER (4 national editor), and AJ PARKER from earlier.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Let’s assume Cranston’s out. Who’re we missing?

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: If Cranston doesn’t know he’s out, someone better tell him. Devroy looks at the TV, part distracted, part annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: Gore's looking at it.  Al Gore? Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 12.

dialogues.speaker: KAISER BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Is he old enough?

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s 38, I think?

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: His daddy could win him the South.

dialogues.speaker: KAISER
dialogues.text: Have you seen the wife? Tipper?

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: And Dukakis, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: Governor of Massachusetts.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Du-ka-kis. That's not going to look good on a campaign poster.

dialogues.speaker: KAISER
dialogues.text: Add a “K". He could win the South. Bradlee watches Hart on TV for a moment. Parker notices.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Gallop’s got Hart beating Bush by twelve.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Twelve? Jesus. Woodward, you know the guy. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: Gary Hart? He could win it. I mean, he’s got the hair.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: How many points you think the hair is worth?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Six points. Four if it’s windy. Laughter, as we hear from the TV...  Applause. Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 13.

dialogues.speaker: DOLE
dialogues.text: I think it's a little lofty for Senator Hart to be discussing our grand future without crediting President Reagan with the reforms we're seeing in the Soviet Union.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: We didn't bankrupt the Soviets. Communism bankrupted itself, morally and economically. You don't get credit for kicking down a door that's already open. Hart smiles at Dole, who kind of smiles back. There’s genuine camaraderie amongst these men. INT. HART CAMPAIGN OFFICE, DENVER. CONTINUOUS. The campaign team sits in folding chairs.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Ribbon-cutting at the end of the week, and then a run-through of the grand announcement, six thousand feet above sea level, at Red Rocks.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Has anyone been able to move him off this weird mountain man thing?

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: He’s entrenched.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Technically, he can’t be entrenched if he’s on top of a mountain.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: There’s a long storied history of announcing one’s candidacy in a drab shit colored ballroom with electricity... and lights...

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: And elevators.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Has anyone told him we can’t drop balloons from a mountain?

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Maybe we can rent a plane.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 14. Wilson continues to watch Hart on TV, enamored.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: We didn’t prep any of this. He’s just shooting from the hip. Dixon gets the attention of a young female staffer, GINNY TERZANO. He motions for a coffee. She nods and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: She’s not the one who gets the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: We'll need water for the press. Maybe oxygen.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: And beer.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Good luck. I moved two weeks ago and still can’t find a decent package store.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Okay, come on, let’s focus. Please.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: We've got a down weekend in Miami. An exchanged glance over this.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (turning to Stratton) You haven’t found the one on Wynkoop? Right around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON EMERSON
dialogues.text: (to Emerson) I‘1l put together some local Doesn't it close at like 5? party leaders out of Fort Lauderdale.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: We’re not doing that.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: We're not getting endorsements?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: We’re not filling up photo albums with people who'll think we owe them something.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 15.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: Anything else we should know?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: No barbecues.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY EMERSON
dialogues.text: Dix... The road to the Yeah, what about the steak presidency goes through the fry?! Iowa State Fair.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not this year.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Jesus. Who’s staffing Miami?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Billy's there all weekend.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: (to Dixon, surprised) You're going to Miami?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Billy B, Broadhurst, not Shore.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Damn, there’s a lot of Billy's around here.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I’m Bill. Only an 8-year-old should be called Billy.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: What is Billy B’s exact position on this campaign?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: He’s a Louisiana lobbyist. His chief contribution to the political process seems to be gumbo and bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: And dirty jokes. He makes the senator laugh.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Last week in April we kick off and hit the road, starting with a grip and greet in Kansas.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 16.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Kansas is a go?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: We think Kansas is a go.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: He'll actually talk about his parents?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: He finds the subject irrelevant.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: How...? Everyone’s got parents. It’s relatable.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: That he was born?

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: This isn’t four years ago. He’s up by twelve points... People are going to want to know him.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Is the senator comfortable... “sharing”?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I’ve never met a man more talented at untangling the bullshit of politics into something anyone can understand. It’s a gift - That he wants to share. And all people want is him to pose for a stupid photo. He will never understand that. Everyone digests this. Terzanno returns with coffee.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: After Miami, it’s up to New York for the newspaper publishers.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Speaking of... What am I telling People?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: People is not a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: It’s circulation is thirty million. I think it counts.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 17.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: If you run covers about the sexiest man alive, you’re not a newspaper. INT. BEN BRADLEE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST. CONTINUOUS. ON THE TV -- CHEERS for Hart.

dialogues.speaker: KAISER
dialogues.text: He ever find the beef?

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: Uh yeah, he wrote a pamphlet on it - Reform, Hope, and the Human Factor. (adding) It’s 94 pages.

dialogues.speaker: KAISER DEVROY
dialogues.text: Some pamphlet. (looking over at the TV) What about his marriage? More CHEERS from the TV as Devroy, annoyed now, reaches o and turns the volume OFF. We still SEE, but can’t HEAR Ha

dialogues.speaker: KAISER
dialogues.text: I heard she looks the other way.

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: Sounds pretty ideal to me.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Sounds like a zipper story.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: What is the candidate’s position on zippers?

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: He prefers them open.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Bob, weren’t you two roommates at one point?

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: When Lee kicked him out a few years back, he crashed on my couch.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: And?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 18.

dialogues.speaker: WOODWARD
dialogues.text: And anything that happens on my sectional sofa is irrelevant.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: AJ says the trail reporters are obsessed with it.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Mr. Parker. Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: (stepping forward now) Just a lot of stories circulating.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: I heard one when I was in Dallas. Someone saw Hart go up to his hotel room with this blonde heiress after a fund-raiser.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Hm. When I was on trail, we were fucking each other, not writing about it.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: I’m married.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Good luck with that.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: Should we follow up?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: It’s gossip. Do you know how many members of congress... I mean, we’d have to expel half the senate.

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: And you wouldn’t be thrilled with who was left.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: I’m not thrilled now.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 19. INT. HART CAMPAIGN OFFICE, DENVER. CONTINUOUS. Where Hart is still giving his speech on the TV, Wilson mostly paying attention and the rest of them mostly not.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Why do they need three hours to take a picture?

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: That's just what they do. It’s the cover of People.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: And they want Gary and Lee.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: They call me every day, and they’re not the only ones. I need to know what the plan is here.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: As in?

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: There’s a ton of interest in the separations, the getting back together. Wouldn’t hurt us to put them both out there. Together.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: The state of things... I mean... Are we talking about, I don’t know, whatever their arrangement...?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Arrangement - Did you really just say that out loud?

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: People want to know the Harts. They want to see them walking their dog, pumping gas, being regular people.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: He’s not a regular person. He’s the next fucking president of the united fucking states.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 20.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY EMERSON
dialogues.text: (aside to Emerson) (whispering back) I guess we’re really not We are not. talking about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As passengers board, we linger on a row where a MAN and a WOMAN are reading magazines. We see the covers: The Bakke and Jimmy Swaggart on Time ("Row in the Pulpit”), Charlie Sheen and “Platoon” on People.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: No, it’s not up for discussion.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Millions of people read People.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (smiling) Oh, it has words?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: People want to feel like they know you. It’s a good forum for that.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Billy. If I do a photoshoot, what’s tomorrow? Talent show? Swimsuit competition? (to himself) A good forum.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: There will be photographers in Kansas.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: And I will be smiling... like some sort of game show host.

dialogues.speaker: PLANE WOMAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Mr. Hart? Would you mind signing my diary? He reflexively takes the daybook and signs it, then hands back to the WOMAN with a smile. She actually squeals. PLANE WOMAN (CONT’D) Thank you! She and HER FRIEND leave elated. Hart nods at the autogra seeker, then realizes Shore is staring at him in disbelie  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 21.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What? EXT. FRONT GATE AT TROUBLESOME GULCH, COLORADO. DAY. A WAGONEER pulls up to a ranch-style gate at the end of a gravel drive. The only sign says: PRIVATE PROPERTY. KEEP About 50 yards ahead, we see the log cabin where the Hart live. We can make out the figure of Lee spreading BIRD SE on the ground. Hart gets out of the car and they share a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary and Lee enjoying sandwiches with Shore. Quick ad-lib about the quality of the food.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Your husband won’t move off of announcing at Red Rocks.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: It’s a powerful backdrop.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: We're going to need to distribute oxygen tanks to the press.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Perhaps they’1ll conserve energy by not asking questions. Lee smiles at Gary. He winks back.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Billy wants us to pose for People Magazine.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Don’t be fooled, Gary loves People.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: That is slander. Their daughter ANDREA (23) wanders into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: You should have told him it was for Popular Science.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 22.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: What do you think Andrea - This time next year, you might be living in the White House.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Just think what my chores will be.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Just think what your rent will be.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: How are the applications coming?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Utterly fascinating.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You know there’s a little school called Georgetown...

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I think we have some pull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray and Lee are hiking. He stumbles for a second and she makes a quip about his age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary and Lee share a sofa, reading books. They’re SURROUN BY BOOKS. Lee borrows Gary’s PENCIL to take notes. INT. ANDREA’S ROOM, TROUBLESOME GULCH - AFTERNOON Andrea is filling out grad school applications. Gary is g over one of her personal essays.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I just don’t think you need the paragraph about the iguana. It makes light of everything else you're saying about yourself.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Says I have a sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I don’t think they care.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 23. Andrea chuckles a little. Gary picks up her GUITAR for a second. Tries strumming. Can’t play a lick.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: So, red rocks?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: A little too much?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: If you’re going to reframe the debate... why not reframe the location. Gary smiles. The kind of smile we reserve for our daughte

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Still getting a hard time about the road trip with Kate.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: We're your parents. We’re supposed to, you know... Just stay on main roads. Call us every night.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: That’s not the problem. Gary looks up from the application.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Kate’s dad... He’s concerned about us sharing a room. I think it makes him uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: One bed or two? A beat. There is more to this conversation. Andrea hasn’‘ come out of the closet, but there is an understanding. GARY (CONT’D) Hotel rooms aren’t cheap... (smiles) Make an economics argument. She smiles and nods a thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flashing bulbs. Hart, flanked by Lee on one side and Dixo the other, holds a pair of scissors over a ceremonial rib  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 24. A large sign reads - “HART FOR PRESIDENT. NEW IDEAS.” We assembled staff and supporters cheering and whistling. Hart tries to cut the ribbon twice, but the scissors are small and dull. He smiles gamely.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Well this isn’t much of an omen! Amid the LAUGHTER, Shore appears to hand Lee a larger pai scissors, which she hands to Hart.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: To second tries! Raucous LAUGHTER as Hart finally cuts the ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quieter now as Hart moves briskly from cubicle to cubicle accompanied by Dixon and Shore, meeting the STAFF. We see dozens of young people at desks, folding tables, cubicles -- trying to look busy as they wait eagerly for Senator Hart to say hello to them. As he lets go of a YOU WOMAN’s hand, moves on to the next --

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: This is Joe Trippi, Senator. He’s handling mail.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Hi Joe. (looking at his desk) Is that supposed to be a chef?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh. (re: a blue figurine) It’s a smurf. Brainy Smurf. Actually. See? Glasses.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (taking the smurf) Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: And this is Ginny Terzano, part of our press team... Hart goes to shake the next hand, absentmindedly pocketin the smurf. OFF Joe’s ‘Oh my god! He took my smurf!' look.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 25. EXT. RED ROCKS STATE PARK, COLORADO. MIDDAY. Gary, Lee, and the campaign trudge up a dusty hill under hot sun. The wind WHIPS around them audibly, obscuring so of the dialog, which is rushed and sometimes overlapping.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: (to Stratton) Can you run this much cable?

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: We'll use a mult box.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: How much higher are we going? The altitude is brutal on all of them, but the Harts.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Just a little bit further.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: The straight down light is going to make brutal shadows. I'd like to shade him somehow, for the cameras.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: (gasping for air) Mrs. Hart, are you okay with the climb?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (fine, smiling back) Are you?

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: (to Hart) How would you react to a tent?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Poorly.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (to Hart) We should hit enlightened engagement before the three E's.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Was Everest not available?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (to Wilson) Huh?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 26.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Economy, education, environment.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Are we calling it the three E’s?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (to Wilson) Not that. The part before.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: I think foreign policy first?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You forgot ethics.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: So there’s four E's?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Gary’1l need water.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (to Lee) What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: You’1l need water.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: (puffing for air) We'll have... water.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: (suffering) .-. and beer.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: It’s got to be the three E’s. Linguistically.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: So we’re losing one of the E’s? Which one?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Ha, environment, education, or the economy. Which one do you suggest?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Add an E. Who gives a fuck?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 27.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (quietly to himself) Four fucking E’s.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Can I get some music? Maybe a high school band?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (quickly) No band.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Music is important. It sets a tone.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: (re: the band) What are we, opening a Stater Brothers?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Where’s Bill?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: What do you need?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Not you -- Shore.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: He’s Billy, I’m Bill. When they arrive at a small bluff, they find a couple staffers and Irene Kelly already waiting.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (pulling Lee aside) Lee, you'll be over here. I think you want to wear something dark, maybe a blue. Not black. Stratton takes Hart’s arm, guides him away from Lee.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Let’s see how the light’1l play.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (reaching for Hart) Did you talk to Andrea?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (over the wind) Yeah, remind me when we —  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 28.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: We'll need makeup for that glare.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Can we have a moment? Dixon pulls Hart away a couple steps.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is all of this really necessary? Brown Palace has a perfectly fine ballroom...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Dix, You know what brought me to Colorado originally? (Dixon doesn’t know) The railroad. I spent a summer hammering railroad ties. Can you imagine?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I actually can.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You know the last time a democratic president came out of the west?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Exactly. The west is the future. It always has been. And it still is. OFF Hart, hair whipping in the wind, moving back to his podium spot. Dixon watching him amongst the grandeur of t giant rust colored rocks. Lee recedes with her staff as aides bicker over where Har should stand. Someone mindlessly fixes his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary and Lee sit for a MAGAZINE PHOTOGRAPHER who is makin minor adjustments to lighting as hair and make up people with Hart’s appearance. He’s trying to smile but it’s dri him crazy. The photographer keeps giving instructions... tension builds when we suddenly...  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 29. EXT. ATLANTIC OCEAN. DAY. SILENCE, except for the sound of the GULLS softly cawing. The sun reflects off the ocean. It’s as peaceful as the l scene was hectic. We linger on the water for several seco seeing and hearing no one. Then we realize our POV is Hart’s POV. In a a tee-shirt and shorts and dark shades, he leans on HOTEL BALCONY RAILING and stares out over the ocean. He’s relaxed, we barely recognize him. EXT. TURNBERRY ISLE PIER, MIAMI. AFTERNOON. Hart drifts aimlessly down the pier with BILLY BROADHURST early 50s, a Southern raconteur.

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST
dialogues.text: He says, Billy B, for that I will trade you the car and the crawfish! I took that deal! I took it! (laughing) There it is, up ahead. We SEE a YACHT with a dozen people milling around on deck drinking. We HEAR strains of Miami Sound Machine.

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Belongs to a guy named Soffer. Real nice guy. Owns a shit ton of real estate down here. EXT. ABOARD THE MONKEY BUSINESS. NIGHT. A PARTY AT SEA! It’s LOUD, and Hart and Broadhurst are drinking tequila from tumblers, talking to LYNN ARMANDT, brunette in her 20s, and DANA WEEMS, a model in her 20s. Everyone's drinking, SHOUTING over the music.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDT
dialogues.text: A senator?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (laughing, having fun) I was. Recently retired.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDT
dialogues.text: Wow. Like, in Florida?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 30. Broadhurst leans into Hart. He points at a couple rich gu across the way, asking if Hart wants to meet them.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Not interested. An attractive 29 year old blonde joins the group. She whispers something in Armandt’s ear. This is DONNA RICE. Rice introduces herself but Hart can barely hear her name EXT. THE MONKEY BUSINESS. DAY. The yacht drifts on the open ocean. Music now twinkling i the distance.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I intend -- as I always have -- to run a campaign of ideas. EXT. RED ROCKS STATE PARK, COLORADO. DAY. For a moment, we see a caravan of reporters hiking up to press conference as they struggle to breath.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Ideas have power. Ideas are what governing is all about. TIME CUT - A CAMERAMAN is on his knees in the orange dust massively heavy camera slung on his shoulder. We see Parker taking notes. Fielder a couple rows back. H stands without podium, framed by the majestic rocks. HART (CONT’D) We are running for the highest and most important office in the land. We find Emerson, Shore and Stratton in a heated discussio

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: It is your job, specifically, to convince the senator not to do things exactly like this.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: What exactly do you want me to say?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 31.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: That he’s going to look like an idiot... or worse, kill somebody. What the fuck is an axe throwing contest anyway?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: I believe they call it Timbersport.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: I can look into light weight axes.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Like, for children?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Roosevelt was an outdoorsman. He killed a grizzly once. (aside) You know that’s where teddy bears came from?

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: Fuck off.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: He’s correct.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: It’s true. Teddy Roosevelt killed a giant bear and they commemorated it by making plush toys for children. It was a national sensation.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Maybe he'd settle for log rolling?

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: How will they commemorate Gary Hart impaling a lumberjack?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Might play well with the far left. INT. HART CAMPAIGN PLANE. 90 MINUTES LATER. No one obeys the traditional rules of flying. People mill around seats and stand in the aisle and perform interview Meanwhile, Hart, chin in hand, alone, staring out the win Nearby, Ann McDaniel is working Sweeney for time with Har  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 32.

dialogues.speaker: MCDANIEL
dialogues.text: Sure looks overjoyed to be going home after thirty years.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: (swigging beer) The Senator has very fond memories of Kansas. He cannot wait.

dialogues.speaker: MCDANIEL
dialogues.text: No one has fond memories of Kansas. We find Dixon, Germond, Broder and Wyman playing cards. W watching them from behind the economy curtain. In the BAC with most of the REPORTERS. Parker watches carefully. An ORANGE enters foreground. A Sharpie scrawls a message the peel. After a big windup, Weinberg rolls the orange u the aisle of the plane. It disappears into the front cabi A few REPORTERS cheer in their seats. We notice TOM FIEDL early 30s and nerdy, among them. He feels on the outside.

dialogues.speaker: FIELDER
dialogues.text: What’d you write on it?

dialogues.speaker: WEINBERG
dialogues.text: I asked where the goddamn food is.

dialogues.speaker: SHANAHAN
dialogues.text: Good. I’m starving. What do they have in Kansas? Hardys?

dialogues.speaker: WEINBERG
dialogues.text: Arbys. Parker looks up to first class. He sees Germond, Broder a Wyman leaving the front section and heading back. Billy picks up the ORANGE. Shows it to Hart. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Remember this time last year? Our bus had a flat outside Dubuque. Parker is watching Hart chuckle in response, when Sweeney arrives at his seat.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: We've got a few minutes now if you're ready. Parker practically hops out of his seat.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 33.

dialogues.speaker: WEINBERG
dialogues.text: Go get’em tiger. FIEDLER NOTICES and pulls Sweeney into the galley.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Hey, when can I get some face time with the Senator?

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: We'll do a presser in Kansas.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: I mean one on one.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: We’re not doing that this time.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (motions to Parker) What do you call that?

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: The Washington Post. Sweeney keeps moving as Fiedler takes this in. Just then Weinberg notices the orange a few feet away, tumbling back down the aisle. He reaches out and grabs it We see the words written on the orange in all caps: “HAVE ORANGE. - GARY.” INT. HART CAMPAIGN PLANE. FIVE MINUTES LATER. Off the flipping of a NOTEPAD, we find Hart and Parker fa each other in the front, with Sweeney watching carefully.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: But you think the president hasn't gone far enough?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I know he hasn’t. I know Gorbachev too, don’t forget.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: What can we do? Aside from negotiate more reductions.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 34.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: There won't be any peace dividend if we don’t meet Gorbachev more than halfway. I'd invite him to my inauguration.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: (doubtful) The Soviet premier.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Sure. Why wouldn’t he come? Why wouldn't we show him democracy in action? We need to be bolder.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: You really think that might lay the groundwork for more negotiations?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Groundwork? The groundwork is laid. A BUMP OF TURBULENCE rocks the cabin for a moment. Gary casually catches his drink. Parker grabs his armrests.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calming) It’s just wind.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Yeah, uh huh. A few more bumps. Parker doesn’t love it.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Close your eyes. (off Parker’s reluctance) Seriously. Parker finally shuts his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're driving down a country road. The cabin jostles again.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See. We hit a few bumps. Truck keeps going. You’ve been doing this your whole life. Some roads aren't paved. That’s all. The plane settles. Parker opens his eyes.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 35.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You got it... So the Soviets are in an economic tailspin, but change has to be managed. Otherwise you'll get a power vacuum, in Asia and the MidEast. You know what fills vacuums?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Human nature?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Exactly. Wars. Dictators. Religious extremism.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: That's your view of human nature?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Didn't they teach you Tolstoy at..?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Yale. I was a history major.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (rummaging for a book) Here. (hands him a worn copy of Resurrection) It’'ll teach you something about the Soviets, too.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Thank you. I’1ll get it back to you.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Keep it. I’m not a library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staffers and journalists exit the plane and try to make s of their next move as they wander towards the terminal. EXT. MAIN STREET, OTTAWA, KANSAS. DAY. The Hart MOTORCADE enters the town square. People take notice. Some wave.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 36. Inside, Hart looks out with mixed feelings for his childh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart has a private moment in the church he grew up in. It quiet and kind of beautiful. An organ player sits down an warms up the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart is midway through an ordinary policy speech for a la group of locals who are listening, but not very engaged.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: As we move toward the end of this long, dark chapter in our history, new challenges lie ahead... Dixon, Wilson, and Shore speak quietly in the wings.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: We flew to Ottawa fucking Kansas to give a policy speech? He’s supposed to be getting personal.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Personal is not a comfort zone.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: If it’s any consolation, He is hitting all of the four E’s.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: We added an E? EXT. HART CHILDHOOD HOME, OTTAWA. DAY. Hart and Lee, surrounded by a PACK OF REPORTERS, stand in front of a rickety clapboard house. ROADWORK is being done across the street.

dialogues.speaker: MCDANIEL
dialogues.text: How does it feel to be back home?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: We...uh... We actually lived in six different houses. My dad, he was out of work a lot. The campaign team just hangs back. Quietly stewing.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 37.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON SHORE
dialogues.text: (quietly) I know, I know. Christ, just say it’s good to be home. Hart kind of notices his guys grumbling. Lee brightens.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (prompting) Remember George used to sit out here all day?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Of course... Whenever I got home, my granddad would always be sitting here on the front porch with a Bible open in his lap. Every day. One time a neighbor asks him, just to be friendly, “What are you doing up there?” Grandad says, “Cramming for finals.” Lee and the reporters laugh. More photos. Hart turns and gives a reluctant smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ELDER WOMAN VOLUNTEER drives the team. They seem to ha lost their way and the staff is AUDIBLY UPSET.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: (prickishly clarifying) You've been to the airport before.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: Yes, just never in a van.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (quietly) Where did we find her?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Are we going to swing through the South or not?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Why waste the money?

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: (to the volunteer) How would you get there in a car?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 38.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (found a map) We can turn right on the farm road.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: State directors in Georgia and Alabama are begging.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: That was the farm road.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Carter won the South.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Carter was the South. Trust me, it’s already gone.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Irene’s right. I’m not writing off the South.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I can give you the numbers.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I intend to be the president of the entire country. Not 35 states. If my ideas make sense in Youngstown, they’1l make sense in Mobile.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: (dryly) And we get to go to Alabama.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: (re: volunteer driver) Dear God, she ran a green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've arrived at the AIRPORT. Everyone exits in a hurry Hart puts his hand on the ELDERLY VOLUNTEER’s shoulder. H gives her a smile and she immediately relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAFF and REPORTERS buzz around the terminal. WEINBERG, SHANAHAN, and a STRINGER read off stories into PAYPHONES. Hart sits between Sweeney and Shore, tinkering with a fir generation, shoe-size cellphone.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 39. Stratton approaches the press corps in the background.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s a 30-minute delay, guys. Go get a sandwich. Stratton walks back towards Wilson and Emerson.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: It’s a travesty.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: A designer suit?

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: It’s not about the suit. It’s the presentation of things.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Ralph Lauren announced they’re doing wardrobe for CBS News.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: You prefer Hugo Boss?

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: There’s that word - Wardrobe. Like they’re on Three's Company

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: It is a television show.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: No, it’s the news... A bad suit should mean something. It’s trustworthy. We see Hart hits a key on the phone and holds it up.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Why isn’t it ringing?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Did you hit send? Do you see any bars?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: (holding out his hand) You have to hit send. I’1l do it.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 40.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (rising) Keep it. I’1l be back. Back to Emerson... Getting more heated.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: It starts with designer clothes. And everyone says - Don’t they look nice - Pretty soon Vidal Sassoon is doing Tom Brokow’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: (poking the bear) Maybe some music.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: Sure, Mark Knopfler’s writing some opening theme song and they‘1l have action shots of the anchors leaping away from fires and pulling kittens out of storm drains.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Hey, maybe they don’t even need to read the news...

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: Fuck, why have newsmen at all...? Let’s just hire models and teach them to read. You know, someone you can really jerk off to.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (genuinely amused) That’s funny.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: It’s not Doug. It’s not funny at all. It’s the Death Nail of journalism.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Do you mean Death Knell? It’s a common mistake.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: How often do people just punch you in the face? We find Parker grabbing a coke from a vending machine. Something catches his eye. He stares a moment, curiously.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 41. CUT TO Sweeney, still in his seat, clocking the same thin Parker's looking at: Hart crammed into a phone booth, hea down, talking quietly with a big grin. Parker and Sweeney make eye contact, and then a GATE ANNOUNCEMENT draws their curiosity away.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: THWACK! An ax lands solidly in a wooden BULLSEYE. EXT. NORTH COUNTRY, NEW HAMPSHIRE. DAY. Two strong hands yank the ax out of the log. A burly LUMBERJACK hands the LARGE AXE to Hart, who wears flannel shirt and jeans. The crowd whispers in anticipation. Quick shot of a gaggle of reporters, Parker among them, snickering skeptically. Fiedler, from the Miami Herald, l a TWENTY DOLLAR BILL towards Parker.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Ten bucks says he misses.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: I’m alright, thanks. Fiedler shrugs. Suit yourself. Quick POP of Sweeney, head in hands.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: This is a first... He might just actually throw away his campaign. I can’t fucking watch this. Shore, munching on an apple, looks on with detachment. Hart, smiling, lifts the ax over his head and hurls with his might. It travels 25 feet and - THWACK! A dead bulls- Even the reporters CHEER as Hart lifts his arms above his head and grins triumphantly. Parker gives Fiedler a little nod. Shore looks at Emerson

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (euphoric) That was incredible.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 42. Gary starts working his way through a line of WOODSMEN, e to shake his hand, particularly after that throw. However there’s a few dissenters including one particularly ANGRY WOODSMAN who keeps his hands in his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: ANGRY WOODSMAN
dialogues.text: (passive aggressive) Just keep your hand out of my pocket.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: ANGRY WOODSMAN
dialogues.text: Taxes are high enough. Keep your hand out of my pocket. The woodsman begins to walk away. Hart kind of smiles...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: So, are we going to talk or are you just going to walk away? The woodsman turns back. Caught off guard and a little sheepish. Hart is unflinching.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s a good place to get a beer around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rifles on racks. Timbersport pros and hunters have formed horseshoe around Hart in the smoky hall. It’s quiet. No o knows where to start. Hart sees the angry woodsman from earlier. He rolls back sleeves, shows his hands, and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Your pockets are safe. Chuckles around the room.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, where should we start? Note: in this scene, questions will come from the crowd. won’t see each person talk. The group is speaking as a wh  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 43.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 1
dialogues.text: What are we supposed to ask?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Let’s talk about anything you want. We find the campaign team on the side visibly nervous.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 2
dialogues.text: Where’s the beef?! Chuckles around.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (smiles) Haven't heard that one in a while.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 3
dialogues.text: You a Christian?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Yes I am.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 3
dialogues.text: You think they should have prayer in school?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I like prayer in church.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 4
dialogues.text: Do you hunt?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Not so much. When I was a kid, my uncle taught me to track bears.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 5
dialogues.text: You going to take our guns?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You going to take mine? This calms the room a bit for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 4
dialogues.text: What about Mexicans?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What about them?

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 5
dialogues.text: They're taking our jobs.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 44,

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (thinks for a moment) You think they want to leave their lives behind? Their families? (stops) Would you?

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 3
dialogues.text: They’11l work for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: That's why we need to invest in Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 2
dialogues.text: You want to buy a jalapeno farm?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Is that what you do? You’re a farmer?

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 2
dialogues.text: I make chairs.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (riffing) So why don’t we invest in their enterprise? Their industry. Create opportunity for Mexicans in Mexico. Instead of stealing your jobs, they’1l buy your chairs.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 5
dialogues.text: They're not very good chairs.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Well, I can’t help him with that. (a thought) I mean, forget jobs for a second, think about security. You really want a chaotic nation on the brink of economic collapse just south of the border?

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 2
dialogues.text: Sounds like Massachusetts. Real laughter.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 4
dialogues.text: So you anti-military or something?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 45.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 4
dialogues.text: You're a democrat.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (incredulous) I’m in the military.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 5
dialogues.text: What branch?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Navy reserve. A couple chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Does that not count?

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 4
dialogues.text: You want to cut the military?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I want to reform it.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 3
dialogues.text: That means cut it.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I disagree. I actually wrote an entire book on military reform. Sold twelve copies. I don’t suppose anyone here read it? (looks to his staff) Any of you guys? Sheepish looks amongst his team. Wilson raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (quietly) It’s a good read.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You say you’re worried about your taxes. You know how much that new B2 Bomber costs? About a billion dollars.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 5
dialogues.text: Worth every penny.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Is it? Sure, they might look pretty flying over the Superbowl. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 46.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But let’s face it, we're building a military that’s only good at bombing. And after twenty years of bombing, you know what we’ll be left with? He looks around the room, genuinely open for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rubble. Rubble that we’ll need to rebuild. And people who hate us. But we won’t have a conventional military ready to fight in the jungles and deserts where they hate us the most.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 1
dialogues.text: Nuke ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Okay. Sure. Who you going to nuke? (long beat) The cold war is over and our addiction to oil is going to take us into battles we don’t know how to fight in places like the middle east, where stateless Islamic terrorism will become an epidemic.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 4
dialogues.text: I’m not worried about some ragheads in the desert...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You should be. Their bombs won’t have a return address.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 1
dialogues.text: Celtics or Lakers?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Nuggets. Boos rain down from all the men. HART (CONT’D) (laughing) I’m not afraid of being booed. More laughter. There’s an awkward pause. Feels like they’ running out of questions.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 47.

dialogues.speaker: HUNTER 6
dialogues.text: If you get elected, are you ever going to come back to this town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What do you mean “if”? He smiles. The men laugh. The room has been defused. INT. BAR AT THE WAYFARER INN, MANCHESTER, NH. NIGHT. Hart gets up from a table of the old guard reporters. The laughing about the day’s events. The CAMPAIGN TEAM is at a table, talking about the next s Hart heads for the bathroom when he stops at the KIDS TAB

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What’s the news, guys?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Cuomo is officially out. The young reporters watch Hart’s face waiting for a react Hart has a small smile, then catches himself.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Long way to go.

dialogues.speaker: MCDANIEL
dialogues.text: Kennedy, Bradley... All out.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I like Gephardt. Al’s still in this thing. Jesse Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: SHANAHAN
dialogues.text: Come on... I mean, Senator, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: He’s got double digits.

dialogues.speaker: SHANAHAN
dialogues.text: You think this country will elect Jesse Jackson president?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Maybe vice president.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 48.

dialogues.speaker: MCDANIEL
dialogues.text: That’s what Jesse really wants anyway, right? Hart smiles just as a waitress arrives.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: They need another round. On me.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: You can’t do that. It’s...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Fine, another round on them.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Word is you're going to be president.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I don’t know, how does secretary of the navy sound?

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Already been a secretary, honey. But you’re sweet. INT. WAYFARER INN. MOMENTS LATER. Hart follows a sign to the RESTROOM. He’s smiling about t Cuomo news. He turns the corner and stops, flustered. Weinberg and a woman reporter from the pool are leaned up against a wall, giggling and making out. Both wear WEDDIN RINGS they did not exchange with each other. Hart kind of smiles and quietly enters the mens room. INT. MIAMI HERALD CONFERENCE ROOM. MORNING. About a dozen editors and reporters sit and stand around long conference table, among them FIEDLER from the pool. BOB MARTINDALE, the paper’s editor, sits at the head of t table. Another editor, JOE SAVAGE, sits nearby. An investigative reporter named MURPHY is dramatically recounting the movements of a drug cartel.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: They fly in below the radar, cruising a hundred feet above the water like Apaches on a strafe run. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 49.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right before they breach our airspace, they dump the whole fucking shipment into the Atlantic - not pounds... tons of coke. A Volkswagon of coke - where they’ve got cigarette boats that kick the shit out of our coast guard.

dialogues.speaker: SAVAGE
dialogues.text: You saw this?

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Got an old Navy buddy. Runs fishing tours out of Islamorada. Spent five nights under a cargo net.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: Nice. Let’s work up some sort of map that shows the route and make sure we’ve got artwork on those cigarette boats in motion. Not some bullshit stock photo, but really kicking up surf.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT EDITOR
dialogues.text: (dry) Got it. Sexy boats kicking up surf.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: Anything from the Mickey Desk?

dialogues.speaker: SAVAGE
dialogues.text: MGM is suing Disney World over the new park. It’s a license violation.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: No shit. Could it scuttle the deal?

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT EDITOR
dialogues.text: Tim’s trying to nail it down.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: Let’s get a top for front page. Maybe some options on a crying Mickey drawing.

dialogues.speaker: SAVAGE
dialogues.text: We've done crying Mickey. Twice. When Universal came to Orlando and when that alligator ate that kid near Epcot.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 50.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: Right. Try Mickey in hand cuffs. Politics?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Yeah, just got back from the kickoff tour with Gary Hart.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: (to Fiedler) Okay. Anything new there?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: I mean, it’s the curtain raiser on the guy who’s going to win the presidency. The ASSISTANT EDITOR, a woman in her late 40s, speaks up

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT EDITOR
dialogues.text: Keep it to 100 twills, Tom. We’re tight today.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: (moving on) Sports. Who the Dolphins drafting? INT. MIAMI HERALD NEWSROOM. MONDAY NIGHT, APRIL 27. Fiedler, reading through clips, has his feet up on his de in the mostly deserted newsroom. Baseball on the transistor radio. The desk phone rings. H picks up. We don’t see the face of the coy, yet tipsy, Da Weems on the other side of the call.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Tom Fiedler - - - Hello?

dialogues.speaker: WEEMS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Did you write the story about Gary Hart today?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (half-listening) Yeah, that was me.

dialogues.speaker: WEEMS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Um... He’s having an affair with a friend of mine.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 51.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re on a street corner. The phone booth is fogged. Insi is DANA WEEMS, a friend of Donna Rice from the boat. Outs bolstering her friend, is Lynn Armandt.

dialogues.speaker: WEEMS
dialogues.text: She's sneaking around with him.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (doesn’t buy it) Okay, right and how do you know?

dialogues.speaker: WEEMS
dialogues.text: (giggling) I mean, it’s all she talks about.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: What’s her name? What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: WEEMS
dialogues.text: (giggling again) I can’t tell you that!

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Look, this isn’t funny, OK? You can’t just call people and make allegations. Now, who are you and --

dialogues.speaker: WEEMS
dialogues.text: She's flying up there. To see him in Washington. This weekend.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: This weekend?

dialogues.speaker: WEEMS
dialogues.text: Friday, yeah. Maybe you can follow her or something. God, she’s so pathetic. Like a cheerleader getting notes from the popular boy, you know? Fiedler finds a crinkly faxed sheet.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (eyeing the sheet) Hart’s not in DC this weekend. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 52.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s going to Kentucky for the derby. Sorry lady...

dialogues.speaker: WEEMS
dialogues.text: Wait. It’s just, I want to ask you.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Uh huh?

dialogues.speaker: WEEMS
dialogues.text: Do you guys pay for pictures?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Jesus... Good luck. He hangs up on her. Shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CAMPAIGN AD is being edited on an old tape-to-tape onli bay. Dixon and Sweeney watch and criticize ad lib. COMMERCIAL: Gary Hart amongst nature. Speaking to camera.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: ... Now over the next year, you’re going to see a lot of campaign ads. Many of which will have some kind of faceless announcer. But not from me. I believe a candidate should stand by what they believe in rather than hide behind some stranger's voice. So, next time you hear that faceless announcer making claims and accusations, ask yourself why. As the HART ‘88 LOGO comes up we find Stratton and Wilson They're admiring all the HOLLYWOOD PHOTOS at Emerson's de In them, Emerson hangs out with 1980’s icons like Nichols Beatty, Hunter S. Thompson, Don Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Must be hard to be away from all your friends back home.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay, I ran the California office. These were my constituents.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Warren Beatty and Jack Nicholson?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 53.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: «+. Yes. They’re both Angelinos.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: On those particularly tough nights, it must be reassuring to look over and see their faces.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Do they serve as a reminder of the regional struggles in California?

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: Warren Beatty is a thoughtful... political... Fuck both of you. We find Hart in the front corner, feet up on Sweeney’s de gazing out the window, talking on a corded phone.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Well thank you. I mean it, Ed. (listens but glances away) Well we will, and Lee and I appreciate it. Hal will call you about where to send the check and all that... Righto. Talk soon. He hangs up and we PAN to see Kelly and Shore.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: You're a free man.

dialogues.speaker: HART KELLY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Until call time tomorrow. Hart walks by staffers pulling out new HART SIGNS.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Oh Irene, tell Steve and Kitty I can’t make Kentucky, OK?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: You're gonna miss the derby?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: And tell Ellie to grab coffee? INT. MIAMI HERALD NEWSROOM. DAY. FRIDAY, MAY 1. A TELETYPE MACHINE printing out the following:

dialogues.speaker: HAMPSHIRE
dialogues.text: Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 54. We find Fiedler eating a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (to another reporter) You never get the tacos. Someone should have told you that.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: But Friday's taco day, man.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Let me know how Saturday goes. The mail clerk, an old guy with a limp, wheels his mail c past the desk and stops.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks Earl. He stares at the sheet. Fiedler’s brain clicks. He starts walking. We follow Fiedler to Murphy’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Hey, what’s doing?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: I think I need your help on something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stratton is attempting to demonstrate the best way to coo HAMBURGER. He’s using a RULER as a spatula and a flattene ball of lined paper as a BURGER.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I know how to make a burger, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: If they see you flip it twice... Others from the team chime in.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (dicking around) What else will he flip on... healthcare... farming subsidies...?

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: I’m serious.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart in an apron, poses with the RESTAURANT STAFF for a f photos. He flips burgers. Parker watches from nearby. Moments later, Hart is at a table facing Parker. A tape recorder sits between them on the table.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (to Parker) We almost done?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Just about.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You read the book yet?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Just about. It’s Tolstoy. Parker looks down at his notepad. A series of questions h been crossed off. One word remains - “Marriage”.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (visibly uncomfortable) Can we talk about your separation. Sweeney looks up.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: It’s a fairly common occurrence. I'd avoid it if you can.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: I’m not having fun asking about this. In case you were wondering.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY PARKER
dialogues.text: AJ... Look --

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why should anyone care? How is it relevant?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER SWEENEY
dialogues.text: People feel like it’s hard to Senator... know you. I’m trying to help elucidate --  Some of us Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 56.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People. Who are these ‘people’ everyone keeps telling me about?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Fine, maybe we feel that way.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: So, reporters.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER SWEENEY
dialogues.text: . AJ, either ask something else... HART (CONT’D) Some of you who were in high school when I ran McGovern’s campaign. It’s not my fault you’re just arriving at the party.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: OK, so around that time, you told Gail Sheehy you believed in “reform marriage.” What did that mean?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: For crying out loud. I was young and tired and living across the country from my wife, and I made a stupid joke. You know, this is why people don’t want to be in public life. Because someone will dredge up something you said in a moment 15 years ago and act like it somehow encapsulates your life.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: It’s just --

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I’m going to answer one more of these, and then I’m not going to sit here anymore. We’ve covered all the stuff that matters. Did anyone ask Reagan about his marriage?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER SWEENEY
dialogues.text: I don’t think -- Let’s wrap this up...

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you ask Carter these questions?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: There’ve been rumors --  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 57.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Oh for God sake, AJ. Ask whatever it is you came here to ask.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: OK. Do you think you have... A traditional marriage?

dialogues.speaker: HART SWEENEY
dialogues.text: (disbelief) OK. That’s enough. We’re done A trad -- here--

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You want to know what I’m doing in my spare time? Is that it, AJ? Follow me around then. Put a tail on me. I mean it. You'd be very bored. Parker scribbles, head down as Sweeney escorts Hart away. INT. MIAMI INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT. FRIDAY AFTERNOON. We're watching the ESCALATORS, over the shoulders of Fied and Murphy. Mostly tourists and businessmen. Fiedler is flipping through a magazine nervously. He’s so nervous, i comical. Murphy is trying to keep it cool.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Just calm down.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Act bored. Most people usually look bored. What does she look like?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Attractive. Hot enough to make you leave your wife.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Honestly wouldn’t take much. Murphy looks ready to give up and then they see her. DONN Armandt walks alongside her. Without saying a word, they begin following her towards the gate.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fiedler and Murphy sit deep in coach. Fiedler leans into aisle to get a look at Donna who’s reading a book a few r down. He leans a little further and is suddenly hit by th BEVERAGE CART, making a bit of a mess. He flinches back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fiedler and Murphy walk 15 feet behind Donna and Armandt, trying to play it cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
