dialogues.text: Donna and Armandt are shown into a waiting cab. Several people back in the line, Fiedler and Murphy watch anxiously as their marks pull away.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Do we know where they’re going?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: I fucking hope so. EXT. HART’S TOWNHOUSE, CAPITOL HILL. FRIDAY NIGHT. Fiedler’s TAXI comes up on a stately, two-story row house Lights shine in the windows and illuminate the sidewalk. No one’s visible inside or out. Fiedler and Murphy fight for the driver’s side window.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: This one here on the left.

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: You want me to pull over?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Just hang a second.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: No security? Nothing? You sure this is right?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: It’s his place.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 59.

dialogues.speaker: MCGEE CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: (looking at the house) You guys getting out? Doesn't feel right.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just give us a second. Fiedler looks at the windows, hoping for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: No secret service?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: He isn’t the nominee yet.

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: Look, I’m not sure what you guys are up to...

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: (to Fiedler) I think you got taken buddy.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: We've been here all of two fucking seconds...

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: This isn’t a peep show, one of you has to pay me...!

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: New destination, we need a hotel...

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Hold on! Suddenly, the lights turn off inside the house. Fiedler and Murphy go silent.

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER
dialogues.text: Which one of you is going to...?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (quietly) Pull over there. The cab pulls over. Inside, they all hold still, waiting see what will happen next. We SEE the front door open. A man’s arm holds it open. Hart and Donna come out onto the stoop.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 60.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Fuck me. Broadhurst and Armandt follow. They walk down to Hart’s SEDAN, all get in and drive off. BACK TO Fiedler, suddenly vibrating with mixed energy.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’re gonna need a photographer.

dialogues.speaker: THE BACK OF AN SLR CAMERA BEING LOADED WITH FILM
dialogues.text: EXT. STREET OUTSIDE HART’S TOWNHOUSE, CAPITOL HILL. DAWN. Murphy sit in a rental car outside the house, as the sun appears on the horizon. He does a crossword. In the back with the camera is ROY VALENTINE, a photographer.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: You're sure they’re in there?

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Yep. Have you staked out before?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (scoffs) I mean, I’m not a paparazzi. Are we even allowed to do this?

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: A few years ago, I figured out most of the planes carrying kilos of coke into the US weren’t coming from Colombia. They're actually coming from the fucking Bahamas. So I dig a little deeper. Turns out, the prime minister is taking pay offs from Miami lawyers to leave beach front runways unguarded.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Wo.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Yeah, “Wo”. Sometimes you need to catch someone in the act. I mean, fuck, have you ever had to do this kind of investigative journalism?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 61.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable sharing) Last year, I snuck into the Magic Kingdom as a tourist. I cut right into Tomorrowland, bought a rocket pop, and when no one was looking, I climbed a barricade and caught the first images of Captain EO. (long beat) It was terrifying, but worth it. A long look from Murphy. Suddenly, THE DOOR OPENS. It’s Fiedler. He’s holding a printed out FAX.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Follow me around. (passes it to Murphy) Hart told the Post to follow him around...

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: “Follow me around. Put a tail on me. You’d be very bored.”

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: He asked _ us to follow him.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Technically speaking, we were already following him.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Are you fucking kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: It’s an invitation. (off Roy’s skepticism) Look, if this were 20 years ago and party bosses were still picking the candidates in back rooms, that would be one thing. But things changed. Everyone forgets that. They just handed these primaries and caucuses back to some folks in Iowa lined up around the Country Kitchen to pick nominees they've never heard of, you know, to vet some governor or congressman from god knows where? We have a responsibility here... to hold these guys accountable.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 62. EXT. STREET OUTSIDE HART’S TOWNHOUSE - DAY It’s RAINING. The rental car sits there. Three silhouette behind the windshield. Inside, they’re eating individual cartons of Chinese. Jus watching and waiting for something to happen. EXT. STREET OUTSIDE HART’S TOWNHOUSE - AFTERNOON The car parked in the same spot. Murphy and Roy asleep. Fiedler looks up from his newspaper. He SEES a WOMAN WITH A BABY CARRIAGE, and then a JOGGER. Then, WILSON (policy aide) approaching the front door. Murphy sits up for a better look. He lowers the window an inch, hoping to hear. We barely hear the DOORBELL. A moment later, the townhouse door opens revealing Hart, wearing a white hoodie and jeans. Wilson hands Hart a thick envelope. We barely make out wh they’re saying.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Hopefully this is the last draft.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’1l give it a look... And then Hart freezes. He seems to be either lost in thou or STARING STRAIGHT AT THE RENTAL CAR. Fiedler holds stoc still, not sure whether to go back to his paper or drive when Hart gives a quick goodbye to Wilson and shuts the d Fiedler gives Murphy a shove.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: What’s happening?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Wilson, policy guy.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: What is that, a speech writer?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: To a certain... He studies the fluctuations in foreign... and... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 63.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Murphy doesn’t care) Yes, he’s a speech writer.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Did he make you?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Don’t think so. Need a closer look. Thinks for a second.

dialogues.speaker: TAGS BEING RIPPED OFF NEW JOGGING CLOTHES
dialogues.text: EXT. HART’S TOWNHOUSE - LATE IN THE DAY Fiedler, pretending to run in a ridiculous jogging suit, trots past the rental car, giving Murphy a furtive glance He jogs onto the sidewalk and slows down as he passes Har townhouse. He’s trying to see through the windows but can quite make anything out. INT./EXT. FIEDLER’S RENTAL CAR - LAST LIGHT Fiedler finishes his loop and jogs back up to the rental and gets back in the passenger seat. He’s sweating... Har

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Jesus, you ran around the block.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Fuck off. (looking for Roy) Where’s our shooter? Murphy nods toward the house. We SEE Roy with his CAMERA, crouching behind a bush, trying to get a good angle.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you fucking kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: He’s young, excited. What was I going to say?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: He’s going to get us caught. We watch from the car as Roy gets closer to the townhouse Suddenly one by one, the WINDOW BLINDS SLAM SHUT.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 64.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fuck. EXT. HART’S TOWNHOUSE - NIGHT A beat as they watch the townhouse. The last glow of ambi daylight disappears into night. And then the front door of the townhouse opens. Hart come down the steps, still wearing his white hoodie. Hart climbs inside his Chrysler. He’s visibly nervous. A stark difference from his usual confidence and calm. Hart checks the mirror as he pulls out slowly onto the street. We SEE the Herald’s rental car reflected in the mirror, pulling out to follow him. Hart puts on his blinker and deliberately takes a right t onto a side street. He checks the mirror again, sees the following. His jaw clenches. His breathing grows shallow. We can alm hear his adrenaline. He pulls to a slow crawl at a stop sign, waiting for the Herald car to get close enough, and then Hart hits the br - His TAIL LIGHTS illuminate the car behind him. We can’t quite make out details, but we see three male fa bathed in a red glow. He shakes his head to himself. Hart hits the gas. Quickly, he makes three right turns, bringing us back to... EXT. HART’S TOWNHOUSE, CAPITOL HILL - NIGHT Hart re-parks the car outside his house. He takes a deep breath. He gets out and looks behind him at the Herald’s rental car, which has come to a stop a few car-lengths aw He puts his head down, shoves his hands into his pockets, heads off briskly into the side alley. The moment he rounds the corner, the Herald team quickly pulls over and jumps out of the car. They briskly follow the mouth of the alley, visually checking in with each ot as they walk.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 65. EXT. SIDE ALLEY BY HART’S TOWNHOUSE - NIGHT The three Herald guys, Murphy leading the way, head towar intersection where a side alley meets a BACK ALLEY.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: (hissing) You were too close.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (hissing back) He was already on to us. As they turn the corner into the back alley --

dialogues.speaker: HART, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Good evening, gentlemen. Standing in front of them, in his white hoodie, is HART. A long silent beat. The three journalists from the Herald line up across from Hart. Murphy out front. Fiedler in th shadows. There’s an eerie High Noon quality to the stand No one knows what to do. No one has ever been here before For better or for worse, they've breached a historical tr between candidate and the press... and they must figure o the next moment on their own.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: (nervous ) Good evening, Senator. I'ma reporter for the Miami Herald. We'd like to talk to you. Hart holds his ground, trying to decipher what’s happenin

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Um... We’d like to ask you about the woman who’s been staying in your townhouse. Hart doesn’t move. Composes his thoughts specifically.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: .-+. No one is staying in my townhouse.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: We saw you leave and return with a woman last night. A blond woman?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I may. I may not have.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 66.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: We saw you.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you think you saw... FLASH - Roy takes a photo. It’s blinding and confusing in dark alleyway. It almost feels like a gun shot. Fiedler steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Hello, Senator.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (registering Fiedler) Tom?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I uhh... I wonder if you could tell us whether this woman works for the campaign. (beat) The one we saw you with.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: She is not part of my campaign.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Okay. Then can you tell us how you know her? FLASH - Another photo startles Hart.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Well... I don’t think that’s relevant.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: (scoffing) Oh, I assure you, Senator, it’s relevant --

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: It’s just that, we saw you leave and come back with this woman. And we didn’t see her leave again.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Tom, you can’t be serious. No one is staying in my home but me.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 67.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: I am serious, sir. How long have you known her?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What kind of questions are these?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Is she a friend?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I don’t know why I would tell you that. Tom, I am not --

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Can you produce the woman so she can corroborate what you’re saying?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I don’t have to produce... This has gone on long enough. Hart takes a step forward, as if to leave, and Roy snaps more photos, blinding Hart momentarily. Hart blinks. The flashes begin to build now, more and more - Frustrating H

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Senator, we know you’ve made calls to this woman. You called her from Kansas. And New Hampshire. We have the dates.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I make calls every day. I don’t see how I’d remember, and I don’t see how you’d -- FLASH, FLASH...

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (stammering) But... Senator... I was at your announcement speech. You said... you said... We must...

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (from his notebook) .+. I know what I said. “Hold ourselves to the highest possible standards of integrity and ethics.”  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 68.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So why am I standing here? Why am I standing here in an alley ona Saturday night? Don’t you think you owe it to us to be forthcoming? FLASH, FLASH...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (scoffs) Owe you?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: You're denying what we've seen with our own eyes!

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: The only thing I deny is the idea that somehow you have the right to ask these things.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: You're running for president!

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I’m aware of that, Tom. It’s in the papers. FLASH, FLASH...

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Then you have a responsibility --

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I know full well what my responsibilities are. (taking a step forward) Do you know yours? Hart goes to leave, but Murphy steps into his path.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Senator. Have you had sex with this woman? !

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What?! FLASH, FLASH...

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should be ashamed of yourself. (to Fiedler) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 69. HART (CONT’D) The only one putting you in this alley, Tom, is you. Hart moves to the back door of the townhouse amidst multi FLASHES... And then he’s gone. A moment as the two journalists and the photographer catc their breath and look at each other - What just happened? And then they scuttle off down the alleyway. We boom up t WINDOW and find Hart catching his breath. He grabs for a phone. Begins to dial.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (through the window) Yeah, Billy. Find Dixon. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fiedler, Murphy, and Roy rush into the room. Fiedler open his giant TANDY LAPTOP. INT. BROADHURST’S KITCHEN, CAPITOL HILL. 9 PM SATURDAY.

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST
dialogues.text: Think. Donna and Armandt sit on the velour couch in front of him

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe you told somebody. Your momma. Your mailman. Somebody.

dialogues.speaker: ARMANDT
dialogues.text: We didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST
dialogues.text: I’m asking Donna.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Oh my God. You think... He's going to think I told someone.

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST
dialogues.text: Donna, darling, I need you to be straight with me here.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I told you, I didn’t -- Don’t reporters follow him all the time?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 70.

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST
dialogues.text: Gary says these guys are from Miami. Which means they're following you, not Gary, OK?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I don’t know any reporters, Billy. I don’t know anyone. INT. QUALITY INN GUEST ROOM, CAPITOL HILL. 10 PM. Smoke in the air, coffee cups, detritus everywhere. Fiedl frantically bangs out copy while Murphy hovers behind. We GLIMPSE Roy, the photographer, in the bathroom develop his NEGATIVES with a mini-daylight tank over the sink, ha listening. One roll is already hanging and drying.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: (checking his watch) 42 minutes. (eyeing the screen) You want to say linked here. Saying she’s tied to Hart makes it sound -

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Professional?

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: No, like ropes and chains and shit. Fiedler grunts, nods and keeps typing. The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Roy) Can you grab that?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: (adding chemicals to the developing tank) A little busy here.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: (answering) Hey... Uh huh... (mutes the phone) They want to hold for a day, just to get our shit straight. Maybe get the girl’s name.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Can’t. We lose half the readers.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 71.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: (back on the phone) This can’t wait til Monday. It’s a Sunday story. (muting the phone) They want to know if we saw the girl with our own eyes.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (still typing furiously) We did.

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: I mean we saw her... arrive.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Interview or conversation?

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Interview? In an alleyway?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Watergate started with an interview in a parking garage. A moment. That word. Watergate. INT. BROADHURST’S KITCHEN, CAPITOL HILL. CONTINUOUS. TIGHT ON the RINGING phone.

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST
dialogues.text: (answering, harried) Hello. (beat) Ok. Hang on. (to Donna) It’s for you.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: (taking the corded phone) Hello? INTERCUT as needed with -- Hart in GEORGETOWN.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Gary! Thank God. What’s happening?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I thought you might.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 72.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: What? Behind her, the sound of shattering glass.

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Goddamnit.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: (looking behind her) No. I... look, I need you to know, I had nothing to do with this. I’ve never talked to those men. I don’t know any reporters.

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Get me that broom, would you sweetheart?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: They knew I’d called you. They knew where I was.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST
dialogues.text: (Kneeling over glass) Ow! Goddamn!

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What’s going on over there?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: BB dropped a glass, I guess. He’s upset. We’re all upset.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: It’ll be fine. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Do you trust me?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I want to trust you. (a tough beat) I may not be seeing you again.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Good night, Miss Rice.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 73. Off Donna as his icy words take the breath from her lungs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martindale exits the elevator and looks up to see Joe Sav already in the lit conference room. They both clearly got pulled out of bed and returned to work. A beat later, we find them huddled over the conference ph

dialogues.speaker: SAVAGE
dialogues.text: It’s not our quote.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: (speakerphone) We need the quote.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: You want the quote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy is still holding the phone to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (quietly) We could credit the Post?

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah... Hart told The Post to “follow him around”...?

dialogues.speaker: ROY
dialogues.text: Is there a chance the senator was being facetious? Murphy shoots Roy a look.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: So now we’re advertising for the Post?

dialogues.speaker: SAVAGE
dialogues.text: We could run an 800 number for new subscribers.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Jim.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 74.

dialogues.speaker: SAVAGE
dialogues.text: (laughs ) We could just tease the interview. Follow up later in the week.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) They're going to find a way to spin this thing. We’ve got him right now. Dead to rights.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: Easy there Magnum, this isn’t a drug bust.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: He was asking for it. That’s a story. That is the story.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (already typing) “In an interview with the Post, he challenged those who questioned him to ‘follow me around...”

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Right now, the Washington Post is in bed, asleep... And Gary Hart is in a locked room with his entire campaign team, figuring a way out of this.

dialogues.speaker: SAVAGE
dialogues.text: He’s not wrong.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: You have twenty minute to make tomorrow’s Al. (adding) No quote. EXT. DIXON’S APARTMENT, DENVER - NIGHT Dixon exits the front door and approaches a waiting car. clearly got packed in two minutes. He hops in the passeng seat. Irene Kelly is behind the wheel. They start driving

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Are we...?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I don’t know.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights flip on as Emerson enters to find Sweeney already manning a phone at a desk. Nearby, STACKS OF HART POSTERS

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Tell Fiedler we can give him an interview with the girl. Straighten everything out. Just buy us some time. Sweeney opens a bottle of whiskey takes a deep inhale, th drinks a glass of water. Emerson just swigs the whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. Murphy picks up with an informal greetin He mutes the receiver under his arm and turns to Fiedler.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: They say the girl will talk to us.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) They’re stalling. INT. AIRPLANE, DENVER. MIDNIGHT. Dixon, Shore and Kelly out of breath as they board a flig The last two people aboard. The flight attendant gives a little look - You made it - the captain is finishing his pre-flight announcement. INT. BROADHURST’S KITCHEN, CAPITOL HILL. CONTINUOUS. Billy B hangs up his phone. He turns to Donna.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: They don’t want to hear my side of things?

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST
dialogues.text: They don’t care. Fuckers are going to print without sources.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Can I talk to Gary? PRELAP: The jarring ring of an old phone...  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the phone ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Andrea shuffle in to pick up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: (groggy) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Hey kiddo, I need you to get your mother for me.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Dad, it’s the middle of the night. Is everything okay...?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Andrea. Andrea stops short. Lee enters in night clothes and takes phone from her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Hello? There’s a pause and then...

dialogues.speaker: HART, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Something’s happened.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: All right. What is it? INT. HART’S TOWNHOUSE, CAPITOL HILL. CONTINUOUS. Hart sits at the kitchen island, eyes closed, phone to hi ear. He rolls the glass of VODKA on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: There’s going to be a story. Tomorrow. About me. A long beat. Lee sighs.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What they’re going to write... shouldn't ever be written. I can’t seem to stop them...  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 77.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Oh, just say it, Gary.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I met a woman in Miami. They followed her. To DC. To our townhouse in DC.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I see. A long beat as Lee absorbs the pain. We see Andrea watchi her mother with anxious curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The one thing I ever really asked is that you don’t embarrass me. Hart nods painfully.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I feel so stupid.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Good. Sounds like you should. Feel stupid for a while. And with that, she hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand grabs the POST, still inside the wet newspaper bag INT. BROADHURST’S LIVING ROOM, CAPITOL HILL - MORNING Broadhurst enters, opening up the paper. He finds Dixon watching Donna from the kitchen. She sits on a sofa with lost gaze. There’s a nod between both men before Dixon le to find a seat across from Donna, watching her like an investigative journalist.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: What are you doing here, Donna?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I just want to go home. Can I go home now?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 78.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Sure, of course. Soon. I know you want to get home. Broadhurst walks through the background leafing through t Post, not finding anything of note.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I don’t belong here.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I just need to know the facts.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Talk to Gary.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Gary's not a big talker when it comes to... this kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I told you already.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I wanted a job with the campaign. BB arranged the interview.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: (has to smile) An interview? Quick POP of Broadhurst and Armandt sitting nearby. He lo miserable and guilty. Armandt reads the Post.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've worked in politics before, Donna?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: No. I just wanted to work for Senator Hart.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Why’s that?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I like his positions. Dixon smirks.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 79.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think I’m some stupid bimbo.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I don’t think anything.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I sell pharmaceuticals, you know.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Ok.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I was the top saleswoman in my district.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I don’t doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I graduated Phi Betta Kappa... I did all the things I was supposed to do to make sure men didn’t look at me the way you’re looking at me right now. All Dixon can do is sigh.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I need to get home.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Yeah. Let me see how we’re doing with that. Dixon rises wearily. We TRACK HIM as he walks to THE KITC where Irene Kelly stands in the doorway. She’s been watch Dixon talk to Donna and clearly has mixed feelings. Shore at the table, underlining passages on crinkly fax paper.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: The Herald piece just came across.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Already?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Didn't exactly wait for comment.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Gary see it?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 80.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: We moved him to Georgetown. Steve and Kitty's.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) «+. Who he should have fucking been with at the derby. (turns to Irene Kelly) OK. Your turn. Kelly looks to Dixon. She wasn’t expecting this.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shouldn’t take much. Kelly nods. A complicated look on her face. INT. WASHINGTON POST NEWSROOM. CONTINUOUS. Close up on a TELETYPE as it slowly spits out a headline. It’s the Herald story: “Miami Woman Linked to Hart” and t image of Hart in his hoodie below it. A hand grabs the sheet just as the next one starts to eme from the machine. It’s Ann Devroy. She turns to somebody.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: You seen Parker? INT. STEVE MOSES’S STUDY, GEORGETOWN. LATE SUNDAY MORNING We find Hart sitting behind an antique desk, unsettled an beat up, reading through a sheaf of paper. Then a KNOCK on the door jamb and the sound of bags being dropped on the floor as Dixon and Shore enter.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: How you holding up?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (clearly shaken) When we talk about a digitized economy, I wonder if we have to talk more about equality of opportunity. Dixon, confused, looks over at the nearby couch where Wil and Stratton sit. The three aides exchange ‘are we really talking about this?’ looks. Dixon takes a deep breath.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 81.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: We can’t hide from this, Gary.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Who's hiding? I’m working.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: .+. We need to say something.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I’ve already spoken to the person that matters.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: There are stories being written. Right now.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: It’s gossip, Dix. It’1l blow over.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I don’t think it’s blowing over. Hart’s still looking down at his remarks. Gary..

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We need to go through some things. This boat cruise I’m hearing about, for one, and --

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Do we think they completely missed the back door of the townhouse?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: It’s not in the piece. They must not have checked.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: If they don’t have her leaving...

dialogues.speaker: DIXON SHORE
dialogues.text: Without the back door, the entire article amounts to -

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - Garbage. Come to think, I don’t remember many alleyways in Florida.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Of course. Florida developed after the industrial revolution. No horse and carriage. It is a primarily front door community...  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 82.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Gary...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Forget the fucking back door! The point is it’s nobody’s goddamn business. None of it is. They shouldn't have been there, period. (beat) Now, if we can all move on.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: That's what we’re trying to do.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I've been doing this for 20 years. So have you. The public doesn’t care about this crap. They won’t stand for it.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: This isn’t ‘72. It’s not even ‘82. It’s different now. I don’t know why, but it is. If we get our story down, we can --

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: There is no story! They can write all this crap all they want, but they will not earn the dignity of my response!

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Jesus, Gary. How about us? Do we deserve a response?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: About this? No. Shore and Wilson look like kids whose parents are fightin

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I’ve got a hundred kids unpacking boxes back in Denver right now because we told them you would do what it took to win. I told them! The best and the brightest. They left families and jobs. Billy left his fiance --

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: She left me --  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 83.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: People are sacrificing for you.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I’m not sacrificing? Should I sacrifice my privacy? My self- respect? It won’t just be me who gets dragged down. None of those kids you’re talking about will ever work another campaign where some candidate doesn’t have to account for who comes and goes from their bedroom. And that’s just the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: We're not talking about that. Future campaigns, at the moment, are not our responsibility. We’re talking about how you get through today without pissing away everything we’ve worked for on this campaign!

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: This campaign is about the future, not rumors and sleaze. I care about the sanctity of this process whether you do or do not. And he’s finished. Dixon pauses. Watching.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Wilson) I want to reexamine the language on page 17. It’s not just the specter of a trade war I worry about. It’s the loss of influence globally. OFF Shore and Dixon's looks. INT. BROADHURST’S LIVING ROOM, CAPITOL HILL. CONTINUOUS. Irene Kelly and Donna sit at the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (holding up a coffee) You sure you don’t want any?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Tea?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 84.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (over her shoulder) Can you make a hot tea?

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Why did Lynn get to leave?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Because I’m not sure you can trust her. And I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You're kidding. Lynn?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Why were they interrogating me?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: The standard practice for a scandal is to get all the damaging facts out yourself - If there are any. So it doesn't look like you're hiding.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: But you’ll keep me out of it? My parents won’t hear about any of this, will they?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: We know what we’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: BB did say you might have a job for me. Fundraising? I graduated magna cum laude.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: That’s impressive.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Do you believe it? About a job?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: You sound pretty qualified.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: It’s just, when you're a model, you know. People just assume.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 85.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: That you can’t be smart.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: (smiles) I don’t have that problem.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: No! I wasn’t comparing.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Kidding. I mean, I don't have that problem. But I get why you do.

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (from the kitchen) Honey in it, honey? Kelly looks at Donna, who shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Southern Comfort! Donna’s eyes widen and she actually laughs.

dialogues.speaker: BROADHURST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well all right then! INT. BEN BRADLEE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST - AFTERNOON Editors and reporters, in weekend clothes, are gathered. TV, a news reporter. Logo reads - “FOLLOW ME AROUND.”

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: They're using my quote.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: (shrugging) Congrats.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: It’s completely out of context.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: What context? The only context is that the idiot says “follow me around” and then goes and fucks his mistress on Capitol Hill.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 86.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: It was a throwaway line. They’re using it after the fact to justify some tabloid bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: KAISER
dialogues.text: Would we have staked him out? If we knew about the girl?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: I hope not.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: So you get to decide which lies matter and which lies don’t!

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: All right, all right, enough! The kid's right. They're just covering their asses. (lost in a memory) So help me this is true. That New Years Eve after Jack died, Lyndon Johnson sits down with a bunch of us, pulls us in close and says, ‘Boys? You’re gonna see some girls come in and out of my hotel suites, and I want you to give me the same courtesy you gave Jack.’ Just like that. And we did. We did, goddamnit.

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: Different time, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Why? Who decides that?

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: The readers.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: And if the readers want to see the candidates naked?

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: Well, that’s one kind of measuring contest.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: What is the limit to our curiosity?

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: Where is he?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 87.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Hart’s gone into hiding. Sweeney won’t tell me where. He’s got a big econ speech Tuesday in NY with the newspaper association.

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: (chuckling) The publishers...

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Iran-Contra hearings start this week? Can’t make this shit up.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: It’s a big speech. First major policy address since he announced.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: Policy? Is he serious?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: All right. Suppose we do something small. Write something up from the wires about the Herald’s little expose.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: Are we going after Hart or the Herald? Before anyone can answer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lee grinds coffee as the radio plays Travis Tritt, surprisingly LOUD, like she’s trying to drown out the wor She HEARS something in the distance, under the music. She turns off the music and we HEAR it. A LOUD RUMBLING combined with a PIERCING WHINE. She stops what she’s doin walks to the front of the house and steps out onto the screened in porch.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom? Lee doesn’t answer, but we SEE what she sees: A massive SATELLITE TRUCK sits at the front gate. Couple VANS sit nearby. DIESEL GENERATORS and PNEUMATIC PUMPS sending loud whines into the sky.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 88. REPORTERS, PRODUCERS, ENGINEERS mill around the gate, unpacking equipment. It’s like an invading army. Lee simply reenters the house, walks back into the kitche

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom, what’s happening?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It’s an invasion.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: I don’t understand. INT. HART CAMPAIGN HEADQUARTERS, DENVER. AN HOUR LATER.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: (on his phone, pacing) Maureen! Listen to what I’m telling you! They were hiding in the bushes, OK? Like fucking scavengers. Is that journalism? Behind him, a chaotic scene with phones RINGING constantl We see STAFFERS answering questions. Joe (former owner of Brainy Smurf) shuffles up and motion Sweeney that he has another call.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hart. On four.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Maureen, I gotta go. Please do me a favor and ask your editors to remember they run the New York Fucking Times, OK? Not US Weekly. (beat) Oh, that’s funny. You’re hilarious. Sweeney SLAMS the phone down. He’s about to pick up Lee o line four when he makes eye contact with Emerson.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: You don’t think he actually...?

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: (to Joe Trippi) You got a car? Trippi doesn’t. Sweeney tosses him his keys. Takes a deep breath, then picks up the phone.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 89. EXT. HART CABIN, TROUBLESOME GULCH. SUNDAY DUSK. An old JEEP WRANGLER barrels up the gravel road, past a l of five or six SAT VANS. It screeches to a halt outside the front gate, kicking up cloud of dust. Joe Trippi gets out and gawks at the truck He turns around and nearly slams into a boom mic. A pack REPORTERS close in on him.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAN CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: Are you with the Hart campaign?

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPI
dialogues.text: I’ve, uh, got no comment for you. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN CORRESPONDENT
dialogues.text: When is Lee coming out? Will there be a statement? A slick reporter approaches, camera already rolling.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE DUNLEAVY
dialogues.text: Hello young man, Steve Dunleavy. A Current Affair. Who are you going to see in there?

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPI
dialogues.text: (bewildered) A Current Affair? Trippi continues, finally getting through the gate. He’s about to keep walking when he spots a TABLOID PHOTOGRAPHE in an old OAK TREE, trying to get an angle into the cabin

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! What the fuck? Get down from there!

dialogues.speaker: INT. HART CABIN, TROUBLESOME GULCH. MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Lee Hart answers the door for Trippi.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPI
dialogues.text: Hi, Joe Trippi ma'am. Here to help.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Okay, what’s your plan?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 90. Joe goes to speak, but has nothing. Lee smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irene steps away from the desk with a room key to find Do lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: It’s only one night. Donna nods, sullenly.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I saw a bar. INT. “WHEELS UP” BAR, DULLES AIRPORT HOTEL - LATER End of the bar. Empty glasses beginning to stack.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: That’s my one time in Miami! Shit- faced, lost and bumming a ride off some lecherous guy I knew I’d never see again!

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Guys in Miami... One of my ex- boyfriends had his car repo’d while we were at the movies.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I still can’t see Indiana Jones without picturing Ed Clausen crying in the parking lot. (they laugh) Another’s in jail for selling blow.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Even my mom doesn’t know about that. Donna nods in agreement as the WAITER sets down 2 more be

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gary's so different.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 91. Kelly flinches at the sound of his name, but hides it.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: He asks about me. Even if nothing comes of it. I feel like I can just be quiet with him. Myself. You ever have that feeling?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Did the Senat... Gary know you were a model? Did you show him pictures?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Oh God, no. Don’t get the wrong idea. I do tasteful shoots. Toothpaste. Jeans.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: You don’t...?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: No! (long beat) I mean... One time, during a shoot, a photographer I thought was a friend of mine talked me into posing with nothing but an American flag. Patriotism, you know. And when I saw them later... (quieter) My boob was hanging out.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Some friend!

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Right? I was so mad. I’m way more selective now. You have to be smart.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: You are.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Thank you. Coming from someone like you. I mean. Look at where you are. Beat as Kelly takes a drink, looking at Donna.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 92.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry you got caught up in this, Donna. This whole world we’re in. None of it’s making sense right now. You should be somewhere else. EXT. OUTSIDE THE MOSES HOME, GEORGETOWN. SUNDAY NIGHT. Dixon, carrying his bag, stands with Shore on the sidewal

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: It has to mean something, right? If she swears it was a job interview. Dixon's looks off, down the street, watching something, l in thought.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I’ve known Gary a long time. In '84 we were in this hotel, I forget which one. Me and Gary and Warren Beatty. And Gary starts wigging out because now, you know, he might actually win the thing, and he’s grilling the Secret Service agents. (as Hart) ‘What if I’m president and I want to fly to Boulder for the day and shop for used books with my kids? What about my private time?’ And Warren goes, ‘Gary, you’re not getting it. There is no privacy. The cameras go everywhere now.’ A cab pulls up. Dixon waves to the driver.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gary’s confounded. ‘That’s Hollywood, Warren. That’s the paparazzi. That’s not politics.’

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: He’s right, isn’t he? We SEE what Dixon’s been looking at -- a FEMALE REPORTER a notebook a few houses down, knocking on doors, a camera waiting behind her. They’re closing in. Dixon opens the cab door.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Is he?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 93. PRELAP: the sound of A WHIRRING CHOPPER. INT. FRONT PORCH, TROUBLESOME GULCH. MONDAY MORNING. Trippi, sprawled on a wicker couch with a blanket, stirs awake from the sound of the choppers close overhead, he r and goes to the screen door. In the distance, A MOB OF REPORTERS are setting up their stakeout equipment for the day and drinking coffee outsid the front gate like they own the place. INT. HART KITCHEN, TROUBLESOME GULCH. CONTINUOUS. Trippi shuffles in groggily and sees Lee at the stove, he back turned to him. Andrea’s at the farmhouse-style table

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPI
dialogues.text: Were you able to sleep? Lee just gives him a look and slides some scrambled eggs his plate. Andrea has her head in a cup of coffee. A rota phone is RINGING harshly. The RINGING stops.

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You could take that off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: It’s unlisted. Not many people have the number. (beat while he eats) Jesse Jackson called.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Just told me to keep my chin up. He’s a lovely man. Strange. Lee takes another look through the window. She observes t news vans and journalists camped out at her gate.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All these people want to feel anger and outrage for me, but it doesn’t belong to them. It’s my anger. They can’t have it.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 94,

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPI
dialogues.text: It, er, it won’t be easy getting out that gate.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: We'll figure it out. I think I’1l be ready to fly soon.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I need to see my husband.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: Mom. Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I've spent thirty years of my life with your father. I’ve made many allowances... Lee sees the disappointment in her daughter's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think I should feel humiliated. Trippi and Andrea say nothing.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Feelings that simple are a privilege of being young. Our marriage is complicated. So is our love for one another. (to Trippi) You married, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: TRIPPI
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am. Just last year.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I think you’1l find that it’s more complex than what they said at the altar.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: You should let him deal with this.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: He will.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREA
dialogues.text: But you’re just letting him off the hook!  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 95.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (a sharp look) Andrea... I went to a Nazarene College. We invented penance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they approach the ESCALATOR to the land side, Kelly ta Donna’s arm and stops her. Passengers continue to stream

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: We've got a car waiting downstairs. It’ll take you wherever you need.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: And we've got a guy here in Miami. A lawyer who can --

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Thank you, but I just want --

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Let me just give you his number.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Really, Irene. I don’t know what I'd have done without you. But I just want to get home. She hugs Kelly quickly and turns to descend an escalator the baggage claim area. She’s having a moment to herself. first in a while, when suddenly - A CAMERA FLASH. Below, we see a gathering mob. The questions are aggressi

dialogues.speaker: SHOUTER 1
dialogues.text: Donna! Donna Rice! Look up here, please!

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: (bewildered) How do you know my name?

dialogues.speaker: SHOUTER 2
dialogues.text: Are you and Gary in love?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 96.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: In love? How did you...?

dialogues.speaker: SHOUTER 2 SHOUTER 3
dialogues.text: Was your boyfriend a drug Do you have ties to the drug dealer? trade?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No... I don’t know what you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: SHOUTER 1
dialogues.text: Was the boat really called Monkey Business?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: (recoiling and shaking) I’m just... Just trying to go home.

dialogues.speaker: SHOUTER 2
dialogues.text: What kind of erotic pictures can we expect to find from you? Donna looks back for Kelly, tears swelling. She can barel see her walking away. Donna turns back around. She looks frightened and shattered. The shouts of her name continue build as we suddenly...

dialogues.speaker: FAWN HALL
dialogues.text: As a secretary, you saw your boss shredding documents... Reveal, we're at an...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irene Kelly sips a much needed drink. Half watching Fawn testify about Oliver North on television. INT. BEN BRADLEE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST. DAY. A TELEVISION plays the same hearing. We PULL OUT to find Bradlee, Devroy, Kaiser, and Broder watching the hearing with fascination.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 97. A CLERK taps on the door frame. He’s holding a PADDED ENVELOPE. No one hears him amongst the ad-libbed response Hall’s testimony. He knocks a little louder. Broder sees him and points to the desk. The clerk sets it down on Bradlee’s heavy desk. He hangs back for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: What, are you waiting for a tip? The clerk scurries off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson and Shore are having a drink. The TONIGHT SHOW lea plays on an old TV.

dialogues.speaker: TV ANNOUNCER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Next up, Johnny's got George C. Scott and gymnast Kristie Phillips!

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Something’s been bothering me. (off Shore’s look) I mean, he sees the entire chessboard at all times. He looks at the country and see decades ahead of anyone. How the hell did he not see this coming?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: He’d say - It's Chinatown, Jake. (off Wilson's look) It’s just fucked.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Are we just spinning our wheels? When do we know we’re dead?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: We had a dinner at Sorenson’s place tonight. Raised four hundred thousand dollars. Wilson takes this positive news in. We see him visibly re

dialogues.speaker: DON PARDO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ...the Tonight Show with Johnny Carson! And heeeer’s Johnny! We hear the familiar opening music in the background.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 98.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: (from actual footage) By the way, before the monologue begins. If Gary Hart is watching, you might want to hit the mute button on your remote control. Wilson and Shore share a look of death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart’s lying on the bed in his undershirt. He’s reading through his speech while making notes on a legal pad. The is on in the background.

dialogues.speaker: CARSON
dialogues.text: I really don't need a monologue tonight. I'll just bring out and read the front pages of newspapers around the country. It is getting so wild that people standing in supermarkets are rushing out to buy regular newspapers. Hart puts down his notes and grabs the remote to turn it

dialogues.speaker: CARSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: USA Today is advertising numbers to call. It's kind of a poll. You can call in an 800 number, one number, if you think the press coverage has been fair. There's another 800 number you call if you think it's been unfair. And there's a third 800 number to call if you want to meet Donna Rice. Loud laughter and hooting... And then ZAP -- Carson disappears and the screen goes black. Hart’s holding the remote, frozen. He picks up a LEGAL PA INT./EXT. TOWN CAR, MANHATTAN. NEXT MORNING. Hart’s in the back seat, going over his speech throughout Stratton’s in the front passenger seat, next to Shore beh the wheel.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 99.

dialogues.speaker: HART STRATTON
dialogues.text: (distracted) Left. Rusting industrial base... deteriorating public infrastructure... declining system of public education... astounding accumulation of public and private debt...

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: On 49th?

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: We’re going in the front.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Has Dix seen what they’ve got?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Right up there...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Billy?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Dix hasn't been back to the office. The car is slowing to a stop outside the hotel. FLASH...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You’ve called him? Before Shore can answer... WHAM! - A BODY sprawls onto th windshield. FLASH! - The photog on the hood clicks away. FLASH, FLASH, FLASH. PAPARAZZI surround the car and BANG against the windows.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Jesus! Stratton jumps out and pulls the photographer off the hoo the car, before hopping back in. STRATTON (CONT’D) Go! Gol

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Go where?!  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 100.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON SHORE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pull away! I can’t pull away! I’11 kill somebody!

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: (opening his door) Get out of the car! Let’s go! Shore opens his door and Stratton comes around, pulling a deeply rattled Hart from the car. Stratton pushes his way through the scrum to the car.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This way! C’mon! They guide Hart through the throng of SHOUTING, SHOVING PHOTOGRAPHERS toward the front door of the Waldorf Astori INT. GRAND BALLROOM, WALDORF ASTORIA. 10 MINUTES LATER. Hart still rattled by the attack outside, sits on the dai next to Senator BOB DOLE. The room buzzes with anticipati An EMCEE gives a dry introduction in the background.

dialogues.speaker: DOLE
dialogues.text: So.... How was your weekend, Gary? Dole cracks a smile. Hart laughs despite himself. Something in the balcony catches his attention. He shades eyes and peers into the lights.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Is that Tom?

dialogues.speaker: DOLE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Brokaw. Is that Brokaw? Here? The lens reaches into the balcony to SEE TOM BROKAW and h crew frantically setting up in the balcony, which is pack elbow-to-elbow with reporters and cameras.

dialogues.speaker: DOLE
dialogues.text: (droll) Guess they’re really curious about your economics plan. Hart shakes his head.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 101.

dialogues.speaker: DOLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hell of a deal, Gary. Hell of a deal. Hart looks around the room. He notices MARTINDALE sitting down along the dais. He pulls his speech from his pocket begins to scribble further. We move up into the BALCONY. Parker sits among a group of reporters on the risers where the cameras are set up. He clocks Hart jotting notes.

dialogues.speaker: MCDANIEL
dialogues.text: (re: something else) Jesus, that’s balls.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Huh? McDaniel nods to a place across the risers, where Fiedler standing alone.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Front row seats. Back ON STAGE, we find Shore in the wings. Weinberg, the reporter from the beginning of the film approaches.

dialogues.speaker: WEINBERG
dialogues.text: Billy Shore. You hear Stevie Wonder won’t play Arizona until they recognize Martin Luther King Day?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Nothing to announce, Alan.

dialogues.speaker: WEINBERG
dialogues.text: (smiles) I‘ll keep asking.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND BALLROOM, WALDORF ASTORIA. 20 MINUTES LATER.
dialogues.text: Two rows of suit-n-tied men are on the dais. Hart is now speaking at the podium.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. Thank you. I’m here today to talk to you about America’s future. That’s what my campaign is and ought to be about. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But with your permission, I'd like to address the events of the last three days that you have no doubt been discussing amongst yourselves. Quick shot of Parker, riveted. Others amongst the press leaning in. Lenses ZOOMING.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Last weekend, a newspaper published a misleading story that hurt my family and reflected badly upon my character. Quick shot of Fiedler, soaking in his Watergate moment. HART (CONT’D) This story was written by reporters who by their own admission, undertook a spotty surveillance... We catch MARTINDALE from the Miami Herald along one of th arms of the DAIS. He rolls his eyes and whispers loudly..

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, man the lifeboats...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: What was that? A frozen beat between the two of them. Martindale gives a and a gesture - keep going, you're doing fine on your own HART (CONT’D) Something you'd like to say? We see Shore and Stratton at one of the tables on the flo

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Fuck. What do we? I can yell fire.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: He’s got this. Back to Hart. Unmoving.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Is there something you’d like to ask me? Or does the Miami Herald prefer to chat in alleyways? Light laughter.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 103.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: (speaking loudly) Senator, this is not a story about the Miami Herald. This is a story about Gary Hart's judgment.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Can we get him... (aside) Can we get him a microphone? Staffers move a CABLED MICROPHONE to Martindale.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: (now on mic) We stand by the essential correctness of our story.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: The essential correctness? More laughter from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: This is a story about a married man who spent a considerable amount of time with an unmarried woman. We’ve never speculated on what went on...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: If I may, it’s because you simply don’t know... Despite hiding in the bushes outside my home. We briefly find Fiedler in the audience.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (quietly) I wasn’t in his fucking bushes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: We know you called Donna Rice several times from the campaign trail. We know she was seen leaving your town house in Washington...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Well was she leaving or not? In your story she didn’t leave my home. Now, you’re saying she did.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: Senator, when we interviewed you...  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 104.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Your newsmen accosted me in my alleyway. Some interview.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: With all due respect...

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: It’s a little late for respect, sir. You ambushed me outside my home in the middle of the night after putting me under some half- baked stake out... During which, your crack reporting team failed to realize my home had a back door.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: (you're going with that?) A back door?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Some surveillance is no better than zero surveillance. In fact, it’s worse.

dialogues.speaker: MARTINDALE
dialogues.text: You do your job, we’ll do ours.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: It would be a welcome change. Martindale throws his hands in exasperation. Meanwhile Pa furiously takes notes.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now if no one else minds, I’d like to discuss something a little more exciting. Economics. LAUGHTER as we close in on Fiedler, also taking notes, wh FLASH suddenly distracts him. Fiedler looks up to see a photographer snapping away at h He looks around and notices other journalists taking note him. He’s become part of the story and he doesn’t like it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HART CAMPAIGN BUS works its way up a hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart, Shore, and Sweeney huddle around a table as staffer work furiously around them. A staffer is passing out sandwiches to the men. There’s a of ad-libbed confusion over who ordered what.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Back to New Hampshire.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Live free or die.

dialogues.speaker: EMERSON
dialogues.text: Wonder how many people pick “die”?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I can’t keep answering these questions.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: One more presser. We let them ask whatever they want and we put it to bed. Get back to big ideas.

dialogues.speaker: TED KOPPEL, (PRELAP)
dialogues.text: Well, you have conceded that you weren’t able to watch the back of his townhouse...

dialogues.speaker: A BROADCAST OF NIGHTLINE
dialogues.text: Footage of Ted Koppel interviewing Tom Fiedler.

dialogues.speaker: TED KOPPEL
dialogues.text: ... And that, therefore, the lady in question may have left when you thought she was still there.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (sweating and stammering) Well, that’s, um... That’s... I mean, Mr. Koppel. Ted... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If we’re conceding that we’re not as good as the FBI at conducting surveillance, then I think we have no problem agreeing to that. But --

dialogues.speaker: TED KOPPEL
dialogues.text: Hold on. That’s cute, but that’s not the point. Did she spend the night with him or didn’t she spend the night with him?

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Right. Well, not right. I mean, the basis of our report was that Senator Hart had this ongoing relationship with this woman who, again, was not his wife. A single woman...

dialogues.speaker: TED KOPPEL
dialogues.text: You have spoken several times, Mr. Fiedler, about the relationship. And of course, relationship is one of those loaded words that suggests that somehow there’s been a tryst going on.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: No. No, I...I...I haven’t suggested, you know --

dialogues.speaker: TED KOPPEL
dialogues.text: Well you've suggested it. You haven't said it, but you’ve certainly suggested it.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (flailing) I think a relationship simply means there were, you know, dealings between two people. There were --

dialogues.speaker: TED KOPPEL
dialogues.text: Well you're not suggesting a professional relationship. You were suggesting a romantic relationship.

dialogues.speaker: REVEAL
dialogues.text: Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 107. SONY TRINITRON TV - SHOWING “NIGHTLINE”

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: Well. No. I, uh, I guess we mean a, you know, non-political relationship. Koppel is not impressed.

dialogues.speaker: TED KOPPEL
dialogues.text: I can imagine what it’s like, because I’m a reporter too and I’ve been in similar situations. Let me put to you an alternative question. This wasn’t a competitive story. Nobody was breathing down your neck. You could have waited twenty fours hours... and got it right.

dialogues.speaker: FIEDLER
dialogues.text: (dumbfounded) I believe we did get it right.

dialogues.speaker: TED KOPPEL
dialogues.text: Is this a story that the Miami Herald drops now? Fiedler looks at Koppel. Doesn’t feel like Watergate. REV INT. BEN BRADLEE’S OFFICE, WASHINGTON POST. EVENING. The sound from the TV fades into the BG. Parker is watchi with a big grin, when he notices the rest of the office h focused on something else. Bradlee is leafing through photos from the PADDED ENVELOP revealed earlier. Kaiser, Broder, and Devroy are experien a collective emotional kidney stone.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Fuck me. Close the blinds, would you?

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: I know this broad. Broad? - Devroy shoots a look to Broder.

dialogues.speaker: KAISER
dialogues.text: (holding out a pack) Gum?  Who? Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 108.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Yeah, she’s a lobbyist.

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: (to Kaiser) No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Run me through this again.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: They’re part of a PI report. A certain Senator thought his wife was sleeping with Hart.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Jesus, this guy...

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY KAISER
dialogues.text: We're thinking Tydings...

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: But as it turns out, Hart isn’t fucking Mrs. Tydings. He’s been schtupping this other woman. We SEE a few photos up close - A smart looking political woman is EMBRACING Hart and letting him into her house.

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: What a town.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: How did we get this?

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: Anonymous package.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I hate those. You got something to say - Say it. (to Kaiser) Give me some of that gum.

dialogues.speaker: KAISER
dialogues.text: You think Tydings sent it?

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: Are we going to even talk about Bush? Hart’s running against the former head of the CIA.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 109.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Not yet, he’s not.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: No return address, no note. Just a date. Six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: KAISER
dialogues.text: Well there’s your other shoe, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: I mean, just because an unmarked envelope lands in our laps. That doesn’t obligate us to...

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: It’s a pattern of behavior. Womanizing. Lies.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: He’s not lying to us.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: Christ, don’t be so naive.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I have no doubt the same envelope probably landed in the laps of three other enterprising reporters.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Okay, I mean, can’t we let some other paper run gossip as front page news. Doesn’t mean we...

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: But it does, AJ. It does now. (professorial) We decline to publish, and then some other pissant paper runs with it anyway... I don’t know, the Poughkeepsie Journal... or the Miami Herald... or the New York Times... And the TVs go fucking apeshit over the story. And we get on our high horse and say, well we still don't think it's news, because after all we didn’t think it was news before, right? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And now the wires are running a story about how we won’t cover the only thing anyone in the entire country is talking about, and, so on and so on. A beat of silence. Bradlee looks to Broder - What do you think...? Broder shakes his head - no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parker walks up to find Devroy making coffee by herself.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Why do you hate him so much?

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: I don’t hate Gary Hart. I don’t think I trust him...

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: That’s one approach.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: That’s my job.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: To pass judgement?

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: To be skeptical. I don’t think his own wife trusts him. Why should I?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: I think you should trust him on the things that matter.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: Okay, I question his respect for women.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me? He loves women. Too much, frankly...

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: He uses them.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Aren’t we being a little precious here? He’s smart and handsome and these women are throwing themselves at him...  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) lll.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: He’s a man with power and opportunity and that takes a certain responsibility. If he was some day trader screwing cocktail girls, I could handle just not liking him... but as our potential next president, as a woman, that makes me nervous... And as a journalist, you should care.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: I think you’re being a little sensitive.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck you. You know what name I'd like to hear Gary Hart say? Donna Rice.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: (combative) What exactly is he supposed to say?

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’m not running for president. He is. And now we get to see what he does when he’s under pressure. He throws a woman under the campaign bus. Devroy leaves with her coffee. A nearby clerk motions for Parker’s attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find Irene Kelly, subdued, inside a phone booth. Diali number. It’s late. A hotel worker vacuums. Intercut with INT. BILL DIXON’S APARTMENT - NIGHT The phone is ringing. We turn to see Dixon in his favorit chair, watching the BASEBALL GAME. He ignores the incomin call for a long time, then finally lifts the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: You're missing all the excitement.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17)

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: (a beat) Thank God.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Looks like we’re turning the corner out here. I could get you a flight. Dixon has no response. Perhaps Kelly expected that.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: What’s on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I just keep thinking... This is never going to be over for her. Every time she applies for a job... She doesn’t have a staff of overeducated volunteers. As far as I can tell, she’s alone. A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got anything for me? Dixon thinks. He can’t tell her that she’s wrong.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Buck up kid. You’ve got work to do. Kelly nods. Sucks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart, stripped to his sleeveless undershirt and still in pants, is doing push-ups. Sweat beads on his face and he huffs. We watch him do a couple.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They don’t have a podium.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I don’t need one.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (to Stratton) You couldn't get a podium?

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Don’t start with me.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 113.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How're voters supposed to believe you?! You've clearly been lying!

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: They will or they won't. I don’t think they much care. We SEE Shore sitting in plush chairs nearby, sipping a Co Sweeney is pacing. Hart pops up.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: (friendly again) You can cite the polls here.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I don’t care about polls.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: (finishing each other's thoughts ) Yes you do. Gallup just came out of the field - Do you think the media went too far in its reporting on Senator Hart's private life? 64 percent say yes. Do you think a candidate's behavior in his Marriage is relevant to his qualifications as president? 38 percent say yes. 52 percent no.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Take that, fuckers.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: 64 percent. Got it.

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: (quietly to Shore) They’1l ask about phone calls.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. I call lots of people.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Right. That’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: Are we going to bring up Donna Rice? The mention of her name chills the room.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 114.

dialogues.speaker: KELLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We could ask the pool to respect her privacy?

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Are you fucking nuts?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: It could be seen as a noble gesture. Kelly looks to Hart for a response, but gets nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: (to Hart) They may ask you about, you know... Women.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: They can talk to Irene or Ginny. Anyone who’s worked for me...

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think what Billy means... Have there been others. Women that aren't... your wife.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (turning quickly) Now you have got to be kidding me! I’m not going to answer that! Not for them and not for you! That’s nobody's goddamn business!

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: That's it! That’s perfect. That’s your answer. There’s a knock at the door. It opens, revealing LEE HART The team quickly begins gathering their things to leave.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: I’'1l come back when it’s time. The door closes behind them, leaving just Gary and Lee. H sitting on the edge of the bed, unsure whether to move. Lee walks to the window.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I... I’m sorry... I...  Hart bows Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 115.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I’ve woken up the last two mornings to the sound of helicopters. They're waiting at our gates. Dozens of them. Trucks with satellites. Their trash littered all over our driveway.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: How’s Andrea?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: She's disappointed. his head in shame.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (stoic) Just to leave our home, She had to climb in the back seat. One of your staffers threw an old blanket over our daughter. That’s how she left our house. Hiding like a criminal. Like she should be ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (stumbling) These people should be ashamed... (adding) The public won’t stand for it.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (staring out the window) Right.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Lee... I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I can imagine. Sorry you got yourself in this mess. (scoffs) I’m sorry too. Gary wants to apologize but doesn’t know how.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I feel so foolish.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Maybe I’m the foolish one. I gave you all that rope and then I tripped over it.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 116. Lee begins walking to Gary.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Were you thinking of me when you were flirting with this girl? Were you thinking of me on that boat when you were making her laugh in front of fifty other people? Were you thinking of me when you invited her into our home? Gary shakes his head then drops it. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Are you leaving me?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: I didn’t fly across the country just to say goodbye. That’s what phones are for.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You think you can you accept my apology?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Not right now - Not yet - Maybe at some point. And that might feel like a burden. It should. You hurt me... and you need to know that. You need to feel it. Carry it so I don’t have to. (a beat) There'll be a time for us to talk about why you did this and why I should ever trust you again. But that will have to wait. When it’s just the two of us. Lee now standing before him as he sits hunched on the bed reaches out and wraps his arms around her torso, hugging She rests her hands on his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devroy is working with a LAYOUT EDITOR at a LIGHT TABLE.

dialogues.speaker: LAYOUT EDITOR
dialogues.text: If we push the girl scout diamond anniversary to page three, we'll have to lose the picture.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 117.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: Fuck. I liked the picture. Is this to make room for the tank piece? Bradlee wanders in.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY, (CONT'D)
