dialogues.text: (to Layout) Find a way to save the girl scouts. Bradlee and Devroy begin moving copy on the light table absentmindedly as they discuss the following.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: At some point we need to draw a line in the sand. We might not agree where that line is...

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: Where does honesty fall?

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: Ask a man enough questions and you're going to reach a point where he either has to lie or simply refrain from answering, which is kind of the same as lying.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: Maybe if he didn’t put himself ina position where he needed to lie.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: I’m talking about what’s relevant. Some paper is going to want to know if the president can still get it up or if the first lady still goes down on him...

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: I’m not asking to know any of that.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: But we’re opening a door... I don’t know. Maybe the door’s already open.

dialogues.speaker: DEVROY
dialogues.text: I’m a reporter. I can only work with what’s presented to me. I follow leads. I look for the truth. And the truth is he lied to his wife and then he lied to all of us. Is that relevant?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 118. INT. PARKER'S CUBICLE, WASHINGTON POST —- EVENING Bradlee walks by Parker's desk. He drops the ENVELOPE OF PHOTOS with a meaningful look.

dialogues.speaker: BRADLEE
dialogues.text: You have a train to catch. Puts his hand on Parker’s shoulder and keeps moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news vans have assembled. It’s as bad as we’ve seen i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shore walks up the staircase to the second floor dining a The place buzzes with anticipation. We find Parker at a t with a NOTEPAD and coffee. At another table, McDaniel, Weinberg, and Shanahan watch Parker with mixed envy.

dialogues.speaker: SHANAHAN
dialogues.text: Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: WEINBERG
dialogues.text: Can you believe that? He just stumbled into a Pulitzer.

dialogues.speaker: MCDANIEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: SHANAHAN
dialogues.text: What don’t you know?

dialogues.speaker: MCDANIEL
dialogues.text: I want my president to be smarter than me, not trying to outsmart me. Broder sits with the older crew - Germond, Broder, Wynman Shore comes walking through and Germond grabs his attenti

dialogues.speaker: WYMAN
dialogues.text: Let Gary know we’re around if he wants a drink? With old friends?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: The senator is unavailable.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 119. Shore keeps walking. Germond takes in the moment. The oth at the table weigh the feeling of being shut out. Broder stands up and walks over to AJ Parker.

dialogues.speaker: BRODER
dialogues.text: You know you don’t have to do this. Parker looks up in question.

dialogues.speaker: BRODER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think you’re the first guy he asked? Off Parker's look, Broder keeps walking. Parker nods. INT. HART’S HOTEL ROOM - MORNING Evidence of Hart having slept on the sofa. Gary and Lee g ready in silence. There’s a distance though they are preparing for battle together. Lee gives her husband a lo She fixes his tie. NEWS about Hart plays on the TV. PRELAP of the press conference - A dozen cameras firing a

dialogues.speaker: HART, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes, over there, Ann.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DARTMOUTH INN BANQUET ROOM, HANOVER, NH, AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: We're in a tight room with no raised platform or podium. stands surrounded by over one hundred sitting journalists photographers. Close enough to bite him. His team leans against the wall along with Lee who stands by Irene Kelly

dialogues.speaker: MCDANIEL
dialogues.text: Doesn't this episode call your judgment as a leader into question?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Yes, I suppose I made some mistakes. But I think judgment, like character, has to be measured in the full context of a career. I think what I’ve undertaken in the Senate, the plans I’ve outlined for the nation, speak to my judgment. I’m not aware of anyone having questioned my integrity as a public servant.

dialogues.speaker: VARIOUS REPORTERS
dialogues.text: Senator Hart! Senator! Over here!  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 120. We see Stratton, on all fours, trying to body-block the c of reporters from Hart. A quick look at Lee. Smiling and composed. Then we see Pa watching her.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GERMOND
dialogues.text: You were quoted once as saying you love danger. Is that why you think you put yourself in this position?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (smiling) I don’t love it that much, Jack. LAUGHTER among the press corps. A releasing of tension. Angle on Shore, Sweeney, Wilson exchanging a relieved gla

dialogues.speaker: SHANAHAN
dialogues.text: You said there’s no relationship. Are you willing to take a lie detector test?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I think the voters are a pretty good lie detector test. Broder and Germond chuckling.

dialogues.speaker: WEINBERG
dialogues.text: Will they believe you?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Well, I think they do. The last poll I saw said that most voters think the Herald was out of line. More than 60 percent, in fact.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: 64 percent.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: When the numbers are in your favor, always be specific. Another chuckle from the group. More shouts for attention HART (CONT’D) (pointing towards Parker) Yes.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 121. Parker and another reporter hesitate, unsure of which one Hart’s pointing to.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Parker. Go ahead. Parker steadies himself.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: (voice quivering) Yes. Senator. Thank you. Good afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Good afternoon to you, AJ. Glad you could make it.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Yes. Senator, in your speech yesterday you raised the issue of morality. I’d like to, um, ask you what you mean, specifically, by that. I have a series of questions, if you don’t mind.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: When you said you did nothing ‘immoral’, did you mean that you had no sexual relationship with Donna Rice, last weekend or at any other time?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I've said there was no relationship. That’s correct. A pause. Parker continues.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Do you believe that adultery is immoral?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Do I...? Well, yes. I do. Hart’s team grows uncomfortable with where this is going.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Senator. Have you ever committed adultery?  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 122. It gets so quiet, we almost hear a GASP in the group. Older reporters shake their heads in disbelief. Lee’s face falls. We can see Sweeney hoping for Hart to come back swinging. Come on... Come on...

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Say it... Say it... Hart opens his mouth, but freezes. No sound emerges. He looks to Lee. He looks to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I...I...I guess I don’t think that’s a fair question. It’s a flinch. The campaign team bows their heads as the goes mad with questions and camera flashes, arms lifting follow up questions. WYMAN, a photographer we recognise from earlier bar scene friend of Hart, makes eye contact with Hart... then goes to taking photos. We see Broder leaving the room. Hart and Lee exchange a look amidst the noise... Too many questions at once. And then quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Harts and their entourage sit quietly. They’re shell- shocked. For a long moment, no one speaks.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Are we doing the last event? Hart’s rummaging in his suit pocket distractedly.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Supposed to have a Town Hall in Littleton. Hart produces a small blue figurine from his pocket. He examines it in wonder.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17)

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: I believe it’s called a Smurf.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Brainy Smurf, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WAITER clears plates from the table where Hart, Lee, Stratton and Wilson are eating.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Kevin's right.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Can I get you folks dessert?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Keep on pushing. It’s early. We take it on the chin and then pack the schedule as tight as we can.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: I‘ll take a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Same here. 123. Shore, The waiter is looking at Gary, who stares straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gary?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Hm?

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: Coffee? Hart waves off the waiter. MOVE TO the entrance of the restaurant. SWEENEY is return from the bathroom. He’s stopped by PARKER, who is holding now familiar PADDED ENVELOPE.

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: I need time with the candidate.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 124.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: (venom) Are you fucking kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Something’s come up. I have some questions.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: You think anyone’s letting you anywhere near their candidate?

dialogues.speaker: PARKER
dialogues.text: Come on, man...

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Oh, and I used to steal beer from the corner deli in high school... I tried coke at Berkley... and I cheated on my girlfriend. Twice. Just to save you the time. Parker starts opening the PADDED ENVELOPE. We move back to the Hart table.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Maybe we move up military reform. Do a big rollout here.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Yeah. It’s just...

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (to Gary) I need to call Andrea. I’1l be right back. Shore finds a couple dimes for Lee. Hart kind of nods as we follow Lee to the PAY PHONES on t wall. She begins to dial. Back to Hart and the campaign team. We begin to push on H as the chatter between Shore and Stratton becomes a low whisper. Just noise along with the silverware.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: I’m all for shaking more hands. I’m just not sure I can get him anywhere near them just yet.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 125.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE WAITER
dialogues.text: Could call Denver, get some (returning) more bodies -- Fresh coffees. On the house.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What if... we booked some TV time. I mean, how long would it take to shoot a 30-minute spot?

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: Saying what?

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Can we pay for that?

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Go directly to the voters. Talk about reporters out of control, invasion of privacy. Hart looks to the entrance. He SEES Sweeney and Parker. Sweeney is leafing through PHOTOS. His posture falling. Hart leans towards Irene Kelly for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Any word from Miami?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: Is she okay?

dialogues.speaker: KELLY
dialogues.text: I don’t know how you want me to answer that. Hart's face tightens. He nods. Registering the guilt. BACK TO Sweeney and Parker. Sweeney now leafing through t photos. His face doesn’t betray his feelings. He looks up

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Congratulations. You just became the National Enquirer. You're fifty cents at the register. Back to the campaign team. Their conversation is down to whisper. The noise of the restaurant continues to build.

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure enough people would see it.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 126.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: If the media won’t talk about it...

dialogues.speaker: WILSON
dialogues.text: We'd need a national buy.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Where the hell is Dixon? And then Hart hears LEE on the phone cutting through the rest. He turns to the PAY PHONES. Lee is clearly emotiona Hart stands up and walks over to his wife.

dialogues.speaker: LEE
dialogues.text: (emotional on the phone) OK, you're home now? And you’re safe? We faintly HEAR Andrea’s voice CRYING as she speaks. Hart slowly cracking.

dialogues.speaker: LEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (on phone) It’s outrageous. They cannot, they will not hound you like this. They shouldn’t be anywhere near you. We will take care of this. Lee’s eyes begin to tear up as Gary pulls her into his ar A family just trying to hold on.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: (quietly) Lee. It’s time to go home. We move back to the campaign table. Sweeney is joining th table, but Stratton, Shore, and Wilson have already clock the Harts at the pay phone. It couldn’t be more clear. It’s over. EXT. DRIVEWAY, TROUBLESOME GULCH, COLORADO. MORNING. We SEE the WAGONEER weaving through the NEWS VANS. EXT. HART’S FRONT PORCH, TROUBLESOME GULCH - DAY Trippi pours ice tea for the campaign team as Hart writes notes on a legal pad. Ad-libbed thanks and comments, but mostly quiet. Stratton looks out the side, checking out t helicopters with bewilderment. Shore pulls him away.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 127. Hart pauses. He looks out into the trees - Vast beautiful Colorado. It’s wild and unmistakably American.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: You know, when General Lee resigned his commission in the union army to command the confederate forces, he had to leave his house in Washington behind. The campaign team turns to listen. As does Lee, even thou she’s heard this story before. HART (CONT’D) The union informed Lincoln and asked if they should tear it down - Light it on fire, what have you... But Lincoln had a different idea. He told them to bury the confederate soldiers in Lee’s backyard.

dialogues.speaker: STRATTON
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: HART
dialogues.text: That’s how we got Arlington cemetery. Hart looks at his backyard - an infinite run of trees lea to red mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time - Quiet. A couple people answer phones Dixon approaches Terzano. Her eyes are red. He hands her ENVELOPE from a stack. She eyes him quizzically.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: (off her look) Cash it before the end of the day. Dixon moves to Bill Martin and hands him an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRELAP: the rapid clicking of a hundred camera shutters  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 128.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In public life, somethings may be interesting, but that doesn’t necessarily mean they’re important. Hart is moving down a line of his campaign team, shaking hands. In effect, saying goodbye to them. At 51, he is ab to walk way from public service for the rest of his life. Each good bye carries its own weight - Stratton. Emerson. Wilson. Kelly. Sweeney. Shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hart enters to find Lee waiting for him. He sits across f her. For a moment they just stare at each other. We can t by their body language that this is the beginning of a difficult conversation. What will be the first of many. B we CANNOT hear them. Rather, we give them their privacy. Meanwhile, in the corner on a television, we see Hart at podium with no notes, giving his farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera scans the crowd then cuts to Hart at the podiu

dialogues.speaker: HART, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Clearly, under present circumstances, this campaign can’t go on. I refuse to submit my family and my friends to further rumors and gossip. It’s an intolerable situation. In the room: Hart reaches for Lee’s hand. On TV: We see a brief moment of Parker watching. HART (ON TV) (CONT’D) But we’re all going to have to seriously question the system for selecting our national leaders that has reporters in bushes and photographers peeking in our windows. That reduces the press of this nation into hunters and the presidential candidates into the hunted. ON TV: As Hart gathers himself, we SEE Kelly, standing wi Shore and Wilson, starting to cry.  Yellow Rev. (9/15/17) 129.

dialogues.speaker: HART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After which, ponderous pundits wonder in mock seriousness why some of the best people in the country choose not to run for high office. Politics in this country is on the verge of becoming another form of athletic competition or sport. We’d all better do something to make this system work, or we’re all going to be soon rephrasing Jefferson to say: I tremble for my country when I think we may, in fact, get the kind of leaders we deserve. The TV goes out of focus. We push in on the Harts as Lee takes Gary’s hands into her own. CUT TO BLACK.
